Sir,

Referring to my letter of June 25th in reply to one from the Department, I beg to say that I have received a letter from the Rev. T. T. George, Principal of the Mount Elgin Industrial Institute, enclosing sundry vouchers for repairs and improvements on the property. I also enclose a copy of Mr. George's letter referring to the same. I presume it is desirable that the vouchers be returned to Mr. George as he will doubtless desire to keep them on file.

Hoping that this is satisfactory, I am

Your obedient servant,

A. Butterland
General Secretary.

Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Your obedient Servant,

Rev. Sir:

Muncy Nov. 26/16

Estimate of cost of repairs to be made on the buildings of the Mt. Elgin Institute, Muncy, Ont. The said repairs to make complete during the year ending March 31/18.

I. Repairs to large barn:
   1. To cover the roof with slate iron roofing.
   2. To place under the barn new supporting timbers across pillars, finishing floor.
   3. To cover the basement floor with cement, place new fittings in place for cattle.
   4. To erect a new silo to replace the one now in use. The said silo to be placed outside the barn. $175.

II. Work shop:
   1. To remove the work shop from where it now stands and place on a concrete foundation, so as to join the laundry on the East side.
   2. Varnish the outer walls with brick.
   3. Cover the roof with slate iron roofing. $175.

III. To paint the outer woodwork of the main building of the institute with two coats of good lead oil at a cost of $3.00.

Total estimated cost of said repairs $370.

Mt. Elgin Industrial Institute,
Muncy, Ont.

The Secretary
The Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ontario

Sir,

I have been asked by Rev. Dr. Sutherland, Secretary of the Methodist Missionary Society, to prepare for you estimates of repairs needed on the buildings of this Institute as outlined in the report made by Rev. Thomas Furnier some short time since. I have advised Dr. Sutherland that all the repairs thus outlined cannot be performed to advantage in one season and would therefore forward estimates of the most needy portions—portions requiring attention so badly that delay can only result in loss of valuable expense. The other items I prefer to leave over for another season when they can receive special attention. The portions pointed out as most pressing portions should you Department be pleased to favor us with a grant, are—The large Barn built some twenty years or more ago & The Work Shop built several years earlier. The Barn is 50' x 100' with a lean-to 30' x 100'. It contains grain & hay storage, threshing floors & silo. It stands upon a brick foundation & the basement is used for the sheltering of cattle.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6205, file 468-5, part 1)
The purpose of this letter is to bring your attention to an urgent matter regarding the condition of our school building. The roof has been leaking for several years, causing significant damage to the interior walls and floors. The current state of disrepair is not only aesthetically unappealing but also poses a serious safety hazard.

I am writing to request your immediate assistance in addressing this issue. The cost of repairing the roof is estimated at $1,700. Additionally, I have noticed that the heating system is also in need of repair, which will require an additional $500.

I urge you to prioritize these matters as they affect the well-being of our students and staff. Your prompt action is essential to ensure the safety and comfort of everyone associated with the institute.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs (RG 10, Volume 6205, file 468-5, part 1)
Ottawa, December 5, 1906.

Rev. Sir,

The Rev. Mr. George, Principal of the Mt. Elgin Institute, has sent in an estimate of additional repairs which he states are required at this school, the total cost of which will amount to $3,000; but he has not yet complied with the Department's request, made on September 18, last, for information showing what repairs have been made out of the grant of $3,000 made last year.

Before the Department can properly consider this further application, it will require a detailed report of what was done with this money, and what work remains unfinished.

You were also written to on this subject on September 18, last.

Your obedient Servant,

Secretary.

Rev. A. Sutherland, D.D.,
General Secretary,
Methodist Missionary Society,
Toronto, Ont.

Deputy Supt. General Indian Affairs

Dear Mr. Pedley,

I received a letter from the Rev. T.T. George, principal of the Mt. Elgin Industrial Institute, enclosing me a copy of an application he has made to you in regard to improvements at that institute. I may say that I visited there about two months ago and found that his statement is quite correct; the roof of the barn being in very bad condition and just as he states. No other improvements I presume are also necessary.

No doubt you will be making further inquiries through your Inspector and if it is the policy of the Dept. to keep that Institute in proper condition it will be necessary for you to provide at least a reasonable amount to do so.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, #155001/5, in which it is stated that the Rev. Mr. George, of the Mount Elgin Industrial School, "has not yet complied with the Department's request, made September 19th, for information showing what repairs have been made out of the grant of $3000 made last year."

I have written repeatedly to Mr. George about this matter, and also about a plan of the land from which the water supply is derived, and from his replies was under the impression that the matter had been attended to. I have written him again today with imperative instructions to comply with the requirements of the Department without further delay.

Hoping this will have the desired effect,

I am

Your obedient servant

Rev. Sir,

I beg to refer to your letter of the 4th inst., and to say that up to the present the Department has received no statement from the Rev. Mr. George showing what repairs have been made at the Mt. Elgin Institute out of the grant of $3,000 made last year, and unless this information reaches the Department very shortly it will be unable to deal with the application for a further grant for repairs and improvements in next year's estimates.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

Rev. A. Sutherland, D.D.,
General Secretary,
Methodist Missionary Society,
Toronto, Ont.
I have forwarded under separate cover the report of the Mt. Elgin Industrial Institute. It is a very interesting report and I am sure you will find it worth while to read.

The school building is now completed and the school is in full operation. The children are very happy and the teachers are doing excellent work.

I am enclosing a list of the pupils who attended the institute last year.

I hope you will be able to visit the school next year.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

As the season is advancing and the time of preparation for our spring appeal, I am anxious to secure a favorable result. The grant asked for will be very much appreciated by the sufferers who have been so kind and the question now is whether we can secure such an amount as will enable us to carry out the project in an accomplished work. Our situation seems to be such that we must depend upon your attitude toward the project. I am sure you will agree with me in saying that a vote in our favor would be most welcome.

I am confident that we shall succeed in carrying out our plans and that we shall be able to secure a large sum of money.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Sir:

I enclose a resolution of the Indian Council at the meeting thereof held yesterday that $20 be paid from the Band funds to Erickson in lieu conveyance of three children of the late Joseph Martin who was drowned last fall in the accident at the Industrial School at Minnedosa. But when he died she mother has moved to support the children, and even before the accident I had written to the Principal of the school that there was no money wanted to send them. It was at the time very hard on the occasion, and the Methodist Missionary would meet the industrial school to which he made his charge to turn the day and evening into a little as they could get the parents and Mr. Brown some money with the children, but having an urgent case, they could nothing help or me but to advance the $20 immediately, since I had the money and desired them to make the payment. I have been unable to reach the school here, but in order to make a good record, I have sent this letter and the three children and family along over the $20 or $25 more, with all the necessary necessary funds over the County.

Sir,

I have the honor to state that in a letter received recently from Rev. T. T. George, Principal of the Mt. Elgin Institute, he mentions having forwarded to the Indian Department, on Jan. 14th last a statement regarding the improvements made under authority of the Department, for which the sum of Three Thousand Dollars ($3,000.00) had been granted. I infer from his letter that vouchers for all but the last instalment, had gone forward to the Department and when we advance the balance he can complete the vouchers for the last instalment and send them on.

As the Department is aware, we have already advanced him two amounts, one in March, 1906 and the other in July, 1906, but so far have received but one cheque from the Department, for Seven Hundred and Ninety-four Dollars and Two Cents ($794.02) on July 27th, last.

If there is any formality not yet complied with that prevents the Department forwarding to this office, cheques for the second and third instalments, I should be glad to be informed of it in order to further advise Mr. George in the case and hasten completion of what is required to obtain from the Department the full amount paid out thus far by him and by us.

Awaiting an early reply,

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant.

To The Secretary,

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa;

The Sup't Gen'l of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

I regret in respect to the fire last night at the Boys' Playhouse. The building was vacated and light put out at 7:30 and under supervision by officers at nine and ten. The fire breaking out at 11:20 p.m. The fire originated in the pantry, store, north end, which being used as a store for flax, straw, etc., kept under lock and was not known to have been entered since Monday morning last when the boys' Sunday uniforms were put away. The great play when entered was found free from fire, as this room alone contained the only fuel in the premises, said pipe entering the chimney into the ceiling. It was done low so the fire could have originated from the premises.

The fire was then broadcasted at 9 p.m., a fire brigade was called. Officers and pupils promptly responded. A bucket brigade was formed under the command of Mr. Brown and proved so efficient as to extinguish the fire in the building in which it originated.

The fire was checked and put down, no losses and no damage. The fire was very large and active, fortunately the fire was small and the fire brigade was able to get the fire under control before it spread to other buildings. The fire was caused by a spark from the chimney, which fell on the floor and started the fire.

I am enclosing a report of the fire.

Yours sincerely,

Sir,-

I beg to report as follows on the needed improvements required at Mt. Elgin Institute as a result of my inspection last week.

Boys' Play House. This building was burnt down last fall and the insurance upon it $2500 was paid to the Department. Mr. George says, since then the boys have no place to go in wet weather except to the Laundry which is of course quite unsuitable. With $700, in addition to the insurance money I think a very suitable building could be erected and it is very much needed.

Big Barn. This building is very large and well adapted for storing hay and grain and stabling cattle below, but it has evidently been built a great many years ago, judging by the appearance and style of timber used in it. Many of the upright timbers are filled with dry rot, and worm eaten, the roof rafters are not properly braced, and the roof itself leaks along the ridge boards. The main joists in many places are sprung, and if a

The Secretary-

Dept. of Indian Affairs-

Ottawa-
a heavy wind should strike it at a certain angle it is very doubtful if it would stand firm. In spite of no appropriation being made Mr. George was working at it when I was there. New timbers have replaced some of the most dangerous old ones, a new floor on part has been laid, a new silo 14 X 40 is to be put in and the roof covered with metallic shingles. He proposes to build stalls in the basement, with cement floors. To do this work he estimates that the material alone will cost $1000, and if he can get a grant for this amount he will be well pleased. I think the expenditure would be quite justified, and that the improvements are necessary.

Woodshed & Slaughter House. This is a portion of what I understood Mr. George to call the Implement Sheds. A grant was recently made to cover this with metallic shingles but more expense was incurred than the grant covered, as they shingled the remaining portion of the building, but Mr. George says it has all been paid for. The slaughter house has not been fitted up, but he wants to do this as in the cold weather they butcher all their own meat and have not a suitable place to do it in. For putting up the slaughter house he wants $300 and for painting and repairing the building he wants $500. The immediate necessity for this did not strike me very forcibly, but the extra work has been done to the roof and the value is there, so if he were allowed $500 for the work I think it would be advisable.
Kitchen. The kitchen for the officers and family is far too small, and badly situated for fresh air in the summer time. Both windows and the door face a wall not 20 feet away, which prevents a free circulation of air; the kitchen corresponding to the centre part of a capital E. Then there is not pantry room. It is proposed to add to this kitchen an addition of about 14 X 20, and up to the main roof, only three walls being required. This would provide a meat room in the basement, a large airy kitchen with two good pantries on next floor, an additional room upstairs and on the third flat accommodation for water tanks. This I consider is a great necessity. The fire protection is not adequate. There are only two water tanks now holding about 2800 gallons in all, which in the event of a fire would quickly be emptied. When I was there they were not full, though the water could be heard flowing in from the pump. I think the main is strong enough to keep any number of tanks filled, and the source of supply as a result of Mr. George's tile drains for collecting the water from the springs on the hill side, seems unlimited. He told me he was afraid to place any more tanks in the attic on account of the weight.

If however this kitchen were built, it would be an ideal place to place extra water tanks, $900 is Mr. George's estimate which I think under the mark.
Implement Sheds. These are at present open and the contents exposed to the weather. It is desired to have them moved further away from the main building, past the orchard, and repaired. $800 would be required for this work.

Work Shop. For the purpose of giving the boys more instruction in manual work, better shop facilities are required. The present building would require removal, it being Mr. George's intention to isolate all his buildings as much as possible to avoid danger from fire. A work shop is also required for ordinary everyday repairs, and improvements. He generally has a carpenter employed all the year round. For improvements under this head $1000. would be required.

Carriage House. $600 is asked for to place this building in shape. At present it is too small to permit driving in and unhitching inside.

The buildings belonging to the Department should be maintained and kept in good repair, and I must say I was surprised at the general appearance.

Ottawa, September 2, 1908.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Re repairs and rebuilding at Mt. Elgin Institute.

These matters have been before the Department for some time and when Mr. Supt. Smith of Brantford was instructed to go to Huncey some time ago he was directed to make a personal examination of the premises and state what was absolutely required and the probable cost.

Mr. Smith's report is on No. 1 of this file, herewith and you will see that he places the providing of the play-house first on his list of requisites. The former play-house was destroyed by fire and since then the boys have no place to for recreation in wet weather. The old building contained lavatories and lockers for clothing and they cannot get on without it during the winter months.

Repairs to the big barn are placed next in importance and as Mr. George had to make use of it he has gone on with the work there. The wood-shed and slaughter-house need to be attended to this fall. The other improvements in the order mentioned can stand.

The cost of the immediate requirements was placed at $4,700.00, to meet which there is available the insurance money for the play-house and the balance would be taken
from this year's appropriation. Mr. Smith's estimate for the total cost of improvements needed to make the school a first-class institution is $8,000.00.

Mr. Ferrier when here not long ago said that this could be extended over three years and all that would be required immediately would be to provide for the three most important items above mentioned.

A letter has just been received from the Principal, who was asked by Mr. Ferrier to furnish a sketch and specifications of the new play-house, in which he proposes to utilize the old shop and reconstruct it as a play-house and gives it as his opinion that the work could be done for about $3500.00 and that it would furnish better quarters when completed than a new building at the same cost. He gives the particulars of what he proposes to do with the building in the letter above referred to, which is turned out herewith.

If plans and specifications have to be prepared for a new building and tenders called for, it will be too late to do anything this season. Mr. George is thoroughly competent to carry on the work suggested by him and I would recommend that he be authorized to proceed at once, as Mr. Smith, Inspector Ramsden, Mr. Ferrier and the Principal are all unanimous in their opinion as to the necessity for the play-house. I know of my own knowledge that the school cannot be successfully carried on without this building, as there is no other place to use for the purpose available at present.

Ottawa, September 23, 1908.

Mr. Benson:

I have examined the sketch plan of Recreation building for the Munsey Institute as requested by you.

The plans appear to be suitable for the purpose, but are not complete, and there is no specification describing the work or material as used except in a general way. This makes it difficult to find the cost of doing the work.

It will be necessary to make alterations in the finished plans giving additional strength to ground floor, providing the work is done as suggested by the Principal.

The entrance to basement is also objectionable in my opinion.

The cost if built as outlined by the letter from Principal George will be about $4500 to $5000, and if built with steel beams under first floor and made semi-fireproof will cost considerably more.

Architect.
Ottawa, October 12, 1906.

To Deputy Superintendent General,

After considerable correspondence had with Mr. George, Principal of the Mt. Elgin Institute, regarding the rebuilding of the play-house destroyed by fire, he submitted a proposition, in which he suggested that the old shop could be remodelled, if removed, and furnish better quarters than a new building at the same cost. His suggestion was approved of and he was instructed to go on with the work.

After that he changed his mind and recommended the erection of an entirely new building and submitted a sketch plan, which our Architect states would cost about $4500 to $5000, and if built with steel beams to make it semi-fireproof would cost considerably more. As this estimate is double the amount available, nothing can be done till the question of providing funds is settled. If the Department decides to put up a new building, the Methodist Church most likely would finance it on condition of repayment.

As Mr. George is so changeable in his ideas, I think that the Department should send Mr. Ogilvie there to see what is best to be done. There is no doubt that a new recreation building is needed and it should be an up-to-date one to round off the school premises, which should be a credit to the Department.

The laundry work of such a large institution would no doubt be arduous for the younger girls, but when they arrive at a certain age they should be taught how to properly cleanse wearing apparel and bedding.

SPECIFICATION

Dynamo-WIRING-and Fittings for Electric Light to be installed in the Institute main building at Muncey, Ont.

(1) General conditions-The Contractor under this specification must supply all the material required, and install in thorough and workmanshiplike manner, an interior electric system to include-Dynamo-Switch-board-Rheostat-Voltmeter-Wire-Pixtures-Shades-Switches-Switch-board-Panel-board etc. All to be a complete installation for lighting the building.

(2) No. of Lamps and Switches-The building to be wired for 100 10 C.P.-Incandescent lamps and 40 switches.

(3) System of wiring-the wiring shall be two wire interior system concealed where practicable otherwise to be run in two wire moulding in accord with the National Underwriters requirements. Lights shall as near as possible be equally divided on each branch circuit.

(4) Wire and Insulation-Single R.C wire to be used throughout.

(5) Dynamo-The dynamo shall be a direct current 160 volts equal to a Fairbanks Morse or a T.H of Hamilton, and shall have a capacity of not less than 160-18 C.P. Lamps.

(6) Foundation-Foundation for dynamo shall be on concrete two pieces of 6x6 timber to be anchored to concrete to secure dynamo rails.

(7) Switch-board-Switch-board shall be grey marble or Slate drilled to receive the Rheostat, Voltmeter, and Main switch. It shall have one light outlet.

(8) Panel-board-The panel board shall be double branch having 16 circuits.

Bus bars to be of two wires-no fuses, lugs only.

Branches to be of two wires each with switches and enclosed fuse connections-to be mounted on grey marble or slate, to be encased in iron box, face with wood and to have plate glass door with lock.
(i) Switches - Switches to be used shall be snap switches equal to the hall.

(ii) Location of lamps and switches shall be as per plan. Lamps shall be of Edison type, 160-p Edison base, and of a voltage to suit the current supplied the building.

(iii) Sockets - Sockets shall be of the Edison fibre lined type.

(iv) Additions - Additions in lights or switches may be made as the work proceeds at a price pro-rata to contract tender.

(v) Contractor is to do all cutting and making good the floors, walls, etc., all rooms are to be made ready for the Contractor by the staff so that his workmen shall not be delayed.

(vi) Work and rules - All work shall be completed in a substantial manner with a reasonable appearance and arrangement.

Mr. Pedley:

I visited the Mount Elgin School on the 15th and 16th ultimo with a view to deciding what recommendation I could make as regards the future financial arrangements for the administration of this school under the new Agreement.

The Capital expenditures at the Mount Elgin School have been contributed by the Indian Bands interested, the Department and the Methodist Church, the latter having spent over $18,000 in the last 9 or 10 years. If the property were considered to belong to the Church authorities, we could pay them $100 per capita per annum, and they would have to make the necessary improvements. But it is clearly impossible to take this view as the land on which the buildings are erected is a part of the Indian Reserve, and as both the Indians and the Department were largely interested in the erection of the building. I think, therefore, we should consider that the Government owns the property and make the necessary improvements. By this decision the Church will only be entitled to $80.00 per capita per annum.

We should assume the payment of the rental for farming property. In order that the dairy farm in connection with the school...
may be properly conducted, they require about 800 or 1000 acres and part of this has to be rented from individual Indians and others. I will have accurate information in a few days as to the actual amount of the rental paid.

In going over the buildings with Mr. Ferrier and Mr. McVeity, we decided that it would be better to rebuild the Boys' Building. This was destroyed by fire and we still hold the insurance which now amounts, with accumulated interest, to $1365.75. In this building will be situated the shower bath which could be used by both boys and girls on special days set apart for their use, and lavatories and closets for the boys as well as a large play-room. It is not necessary to have the lavatories for the boys in the Main Building because they do not wash in the morning until after their work is done before they go to breakfast.

The school-room accommodation in what is called the Annex will be sufficient, as the large room now used for a chapel in the Main Building can be used as a class-room from time to time if necessary.

The water closets in the dormitories should have cement floors under and surrounding them and there are some necessary improvements to be made in the girls' lavatories and water closets in the basement (as detailed by Mr. Ogilvie in his report) as the accommodation is by no means sufficient.

The Laundry Building also requires to have some

REPORT OF THE MOUNT ELGIN INSTITUTE
YEAR ENDING MARCH 31, 1911.

BUILDINGS.

The main building is kept neat and clean. Considerable furnishings have been put in and some improvements made, the most important being new ranges for the kitchens, some good furniture and the installation of an electric light plant which furnishes light for the main buildings, cottages, laundry, stable and barns. The light plant was put in by the Government at a cost of about $2,400, also $500 for the material in a new hen house.

CLASS ROOMS.

The half day system is carried out for most of the older scholars, while many of the younger attend the class rooms all day.

The teachers are doing good work and up-to-date methods are in vogue, especially in the senior rooms, where a class of nine are in preparation for the Entrance examinations in July.

LIVE STOCK.

There are at present 196 head of cattle, 31 horses, and 74 pigs, all looking well for this season of the year. 70 cattle, 10 horses and 40 pigs, and a total increase of about $6,000 in the value of the live stock have been added since July, 1909.

CHILDREN AND STAFF.

The health of all has been very good, the doctor's bill and drug account being only $35 for the past year and nine months.

The conduct of the pupils has been worthy of praise, and they have greatly assisted the Principal and his staff to create a homelike atmosphere about the entire Institution. There are 108 children in attendance.

THE FUTURE MANAGEMENT OF THIS INSTITUTE.

I paid a visit to Ottawa and discussed the basis of a new agreement with the Deputy Minister and the Superintendent of the Education Department. Two propositions were under consideration:

1. The Church to make certain needed repairs to bring the school into Class "A." This would involve an outlay of about $8,000, and keep the place in repair five years to year. This would involve about $1,000 a year, and the Government would give a grant of $100 per pupil for 100 pupils.

2. The Government to make all needed repairs and in so doing provide accommodation for 125 pupils, and keep the entire plant in repair; also pay the rents, which have averaged $900 per year for the last seven years, and give the management $60 per pupil.

Dear Mr. Ross,

With further reference to the proposed improvements at the M. Elgin Institute I have to inform you that it has been thought advisable not to proceed with the erection of the Boys' play-room this summer but to postpone that until next year.

It is thought to be a matter of great importance to remodel the heating apparatus before next winter. At present the main building and the annex are heated by separate hot water furnaces, but the one in the main building is inadequate and does not heat the building properly. What we propose to do is to change the hot water system into a low pressure steam system and heat the group of buildings from a central boiler station, including the proposed new building for the boys' play-room, which I have just mentioned, when it is erected. The cubic contents of this building would be about 63,000 cubic feet, and from this the Steam-Fitters can tell what the strength of the boilers should be. It is highly desirable, therefore, to have a proper heating plan, with an estimate of the cost, in order that the work may be undertaken at as early a date as possible - with a guarantee that it will be completed before it is necessary to use it.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum

Ass't Deputy and Secretary,

I beg to inform you that on Tuesday, January 2nd, I made an inspection of the Muncey Indian Institute, Muncey, Ont., and to report that the new Hot Water Heating System has been completed, as contracted for, and is now in operation and successfully heats the building; also that four new sanitary W.C.'s have been installed in the dormitories (one in each) with new soil pipe of increased size and all connected with the drainage system also in the girls' lavatory in basement, the additional basins necessary for this portion of their equipment.

The new engine house has been lined up inside with dressed boarding, and concrete floor laid throughout this building.

A new wood shed attached to laundry building extending to the ice-house has also been constructed enclosed on three sides with open front. This was very necessary and enables them to keep their fuel dry as well as the preparation of it under cover during stormy weather.

The work done as enumerated above, so far as I could judge in its completed state, is satisfactory and the old chimney flues to which the boilers are connected, although contracted, are apparently giving satisfactory results.

The boilers installed are of sufficient capacity to heat the new wings which it is proposed to erect to enable the to successfully operate the school under the new contract.

Architect.

Toronto Metallic Washers

Most laundrymen have learned by experience that the better the appliance the better the work, and with that truism established it is a recognized fact that the washroom, the foundation for good work, must have the best washing machines that can be constructed. The Brass Washer has been constructed to meet every requirement. A fault of the ordinary Washer is that excessive loads weaken its parts. The Brass Washer is impregnable and the solidity precludes the possibility of wear, thus giving superior durability.

From the sanitary standpoint this Washer is an ideal invention. Cleanliness is a paramount requisite in the washroom. The wood washer is an absorber and accumulator of the unclean dregs of the washing process; it holds the scum that rises to the surface and creates a condition detrimental to producing good clean work. The Brass Washer prevents all such difficulties, is easily cleaned, stays clean longer and cannot retain dirt or impurity. We furnish these Machines in either galvanized case and iron ends with brass cylinder, or wooden case with brass cylinder, or brass case and brass cylinder. Our Sterilizer or Disinfecting Washers are finished in the same first-class manner.

GENERAL DESCRIPTION OF THE CONSTRUCTION OF TORONTO METALLIC WASHERS

The OUTER CASE is constructed of two sheets of No. 10 gauge galvanized steel. These sheets are fabricated and rolled before being galvanized which insures them against the possibility of rusting by reason of the edges and openings being raw and which are not protected by the galvanizing. These sheets on all end movement machines are the full half circumference of the outer case, while on the Elevated Movement Machines the lower sheet extends from the front opening for two-thirds of the circumference. On all types of Toronto Metallic Washers these sheets are inserted into a slot cast in the iron heads. The two heads are drawn up tightly against the sheets by means of bronze tie bolts, ½ inch diameter.

These sheets are NOT RIVETTED as they used to be in the older type of machine and a special water tight slip joint is provided where the upper and lower sheets meet both at the front and rear of the machine. These joints are self locking and are not riveted or bolted. To remove the upper half of the outer shell requires the loosening of only a few bolts in the flanges where the upper and lower parts of the cast iron heads are joined together.

A reference to the several half tone engravings will illustrate this system, and they also show combination head with the legs cast all in one piece. The bands upon the outer case are of galvanized iron and the sliding doors on all Metallic Washers are made of No. 14 hard sheet brass with bronze handles. These brass doors are the result of years of experience, and have proved a solution of the difficulty usually experienced with galvanized doors, which on account of their constant use commence to rust inside the slides as soon as the galvanizing wears off, with the result that the doors after a short time become very stiff in sliding backwards and forwards.
Toronto Metallic Washers

CYLINDER. The cylinders of all Toronto Metallic Washers are constructed of No. 13 half hard sheet brass with the perforations doubly embossed. Each cylinder has seven formed sheet brass ribs through which are passed \( \frac{3}{4} \) inch truss bolts for securing the galvanized cast iron trunnions. The brass sheets on each end of the inner cylinder are 1-16 inch in thickness of hard sheet brass the full diameter of the cylinder. The galvanized cast iron trunnions have inwardly projecting flanges on the inside of which the brass sheets forming the cylinder are securely riveted. On all machines over 50 inches in length two doors are provided on both the inner cylinder and the outer case. The doors on the inner cylinder having hinges, catches, leeks, etc., all of solid brass.

GEARS. The gears are all machine cut from solid castings and are protected with gear cases as shown in the several illustrations. These machines are all fitted with the Toronto lever handle, bottom discharge washer valves with full three inch opening. The water inlet is three inches and the steam inlet one-half inch. The Standard Machines are fitted with the discharge on the right hand end and the water and steam inlets and gauge glass upon the left hand end, but these may be reversed if we are so instructed when the machine is ordered.

REVERSING MOVEMENT. The header is of our well-known type and is clearly shown in the several cuts. This is one of the most simple headers in use today and consists of about a dozen pieces, including the belt loops.

JOURNALS. The main or cylinder journals are three inches diameter by eight inches long of phosphor bronze made to standard gauge and templet and may be renewed without removing the cylinder from its case.

Sterilizer Washers

The above specifications also cover our Sterilizer Washers, which are designed for disinfecting as well as washing the goods. These washers are provided with heavy doors and clamps for securely fastening the same, and are provided with an opening for a four inch diameter ventilating pipe, which should be connected with the chimney or carried outside of the laundry room to carry off the odors from the goods while cleaning them. The construction of this machine is such that the goods may be washed at a high temperature, thereby thoroughly disinfecting them.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your favor of the 3rd inst regarding installation of machinery at Mount Elgin Industrial School, would state that the writer went out there a few days ago to look the situation over, to see what was needed in order to make proper connections, etc., for the new machinery to be installed.

We find that the old machinery in use at present cannot continue to be used as it stands at present without some additional fittings.

When figuring on our cost therefore, we did not figure on fixing up the old machinery but on going out there we were advised by Mr. McVitty that the old machinery would also require to be used, particularly the washer as one machine would not be able to do the work promptly.

Now, in order to make a satisfactory job of the matter we find that a good many of the old pipes, fittings, etc., including belting, pulleys, couplings, and many other things of a like nature would have to be torn down entirely, and new ones put in. As a matter of fact we are very much surprised that no accidents have happened owing to the state that the Machinery, etc., is in.

Now, in addition to the machinery which was ordered to be installed, we find that a 500 gallon cypress water tank 3'4" in diameter by 6'5" high, ought to be installed, together with one only double acting power driven pump for pumping used water back to washers, should be installed.

These items are necessary because very often during the summer months the supply of water is very limited and owing
To the large quantity used in washing, the water must be saved to a certain extent, and the above will be necessary in order to do this.

Now of course it is not necessary to act on our suggestion in this matter, but we feel that if you wish to fit up this Laundry so that it will be in shape for the next ten years you ought to do something of the nature suggested by us, as well as tear out a lot of old fittings, shaffing, etc., which it is positively dangerous to use at the present time.

Now, we find that if you wish us to do all of this together with special tank and pump, that the total cost of the work will be $750.00. If of course you do not wish us to supply work and labor, together with new fittings, which really are badly needed, and which were not figured on in the original estimate, that of course we come within the limit of $750.00 set by you.

Now, we think that in our humble estimation that the matter is urgently needed, and if you desire we shall be very glad to have you take up the matter with our Mr. McVitty, asking him his opinion on the matter.

We await your prompt reply in the matter, as we are prepared to go ahead at once with the contract.

Yours very truly,

WIT/B.

THOMAS BROTHERS LTD.

I have the honor to report that as instructed by your official letter of the 3rd instant I proceeded to Muncey for the purpose of inspecting the work on the additions to the Mount Elgin Institute and have to report that I went to the building from St. Thomas with the contractor, Mr. A. Poreford and after having the basement excavations levelled for the footings and the forms set, the contractors commenced laying the concrete footings of the girls' wing; the work on footings of boys' and girls' building being completed on Thursday last.

There is no material on the ground for the balance of the form work, I learned, however, after arriving in St. Thomas that the car would be received that day and the material immediately removed therefrom to the building site. The construction of the forms would be immediately proceeded with.

The material used for the concrete is river gravel (no broken stone being available), this is slow setting if sufficient care is taken in preparation of the good concrete. The mixer in use, however, is very efficient and the measure of the materials is by hand to avoid mistakes and in this way requires constant and careful oversight to ensure satisfactory work.
and I would, therefore, recommend that an inspector be immediately employed in constant supervision, at least, until the concrete walls are completed and as Mr. McVitty is residing there and has had considerable building experience and will undertake the supervision at a per diem allowance of five dollars ($5.) covering all his expenses I would recommend that he be employed.

While in St. Thomas I interviewed the several subcontractors with respect to materials, specified to be used in the building, particularly as several changes are requested owing to the difficulty of obtaining some of the materials there, it is proposed, however, to use even better materials than those specified and I informed them that the official consent of the Department would be given to them for these changes.

Memorandum

to Mr. Pedley,

The verandah referred to in letter of the Principal of Mount Elgin Institute, and attached hereto, is erected at the front of the school and while being of good condition is of rather meagre proportions for a building of this size. The suggested extension can be made by carrying out the angles of verandah at each side of main entrance, square instead of following the lines of the front of building.

To provide the additional space asked for, utilizing the material now in verandah and that specified for the extension, will probably cost $150. or if new and larger posts and piers are put in $300. If an entirely new and heavier verandah designed on modern lines and corresponding with the building in appearance, is built, the cost will be about $800. or $900. In either case the extra room provided will be about equal, the added space being about 162 sq. feet.

I would recommend that the modern verandah be provided if funds are available and if insufficient for that purpose, that the first plan be adopted.
The Principal also asks to have the old six inch main drain carrying the sewage from the buildings to the river replaced with ten inch tile owing to constant obstruction through insufficient size in the smaller drain.

The estimated cost of 1,000 feet of ten inch tile delivered at Muncey station f.o.b. will be $300. The cartage from station and laying of tiles will probably be done by the school free of cost to the Department.

I would recommend that the new drain be provided.

Architect.

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of the 3rd inst., permit me to say,

1. The work was absolutely necessary. Practically nothing had been done to the Principal's apartments for years.

2. My wife intended having a few friends visit her in the Spring, and wanted her house at least decent. She has, since coming here, served this school in almost every capacity, from matron to cook, as necessity demanded, and without a cent of remuneration.

3. The carpenters were on the ground, they had the flooring left over and offered it at mill prices laid down here. Mr. Brown, who has done practically all the painting and decorating for years, was about to move to Detroit, we had barely time to get the work done before he left. It is almost impossible to get really good workmen to come out here when there is so great demand for them in the city.

4. All this came upon me suddenly, and had I waited for permission of the Department, these men would have been gone and we could not have got the work done. I simply did what is often done, in fact what often has to be done, do the thing that is necessary and hope for the best in the matter of having it recognized.

Since the new arrangement was entered into, we have spent hundreds of dollars on small necessary repairs which we
have not reported at all.

We know our action, in this case was irregular, therefore as a penalty upon ourselves, we offered to pay half the account. At the present time we are painting the barns and stables, the paint has cost us about $130.00, and we are paying good wages to our mechanic to superintend the work. It is a great job and the Department ought to feel proud of the plant here. Neither a Government or Church can afford to be identified with a broken down affair.

Give us a good generous settlement of this matter, paint and all, and we will promise faithfully not to offend again.

Ask Mr. Inspector Mc.Gibbon, who has been here recently, what he thinks of the work being done.

I am, Dear Sir,

Yours Respectfully,

In reply to yours of the 3rd Inst., permit me to say,

1. The work was absolutely necessary. Practically nothing had been done to the Principal's apartments for years.

2. My wife intended having a few friends visit her in the Spring, and wanted her house at least decent. She has, since coming here, served this school in almost every capacity, from matron to cook, as necessity demanded, and without a cent of remuneration.

3. The carpenters were on the ground, they had the flooring left over and offered it at mill prices laid down here. Mr. Brown, who has done practically all the painting and decorating for years, was about to move to Detroit, we had barely time to get the work done before he left. It is almost impossible to get really good workmen to come out here when there is so great demand for them in the city.

4. All this came upon me suddenly, and had I waited for permission of the Department, these men would have been gone and we could not have got the work done. I simply did what is often done, in fact what often has to be done, do the thing that is necessary and hope for the best in the matter of having it recognized.

Since the new arrangement was entered into, we have spent hundreds of dollars on small necessary repairs which we
have not reported at all.

We know our action, in this case was irregular, therefore as a penalty upon ourselves, we offered to pay the account. At the present time we are painting the barns and stables, the paint has cost us about $150.00, and we are paying good wages to our mechanic to superintend the work. It is a great job and the Department ought to feel proud of the plant here. Neither a Government or Church can afford to be identified with a broken down affair.

Give us a good generous settlement of this matter, paint and all, and we will promise faithfully not to offend again.

Ask Mr. Inspector Mc.Gibbon, who has been here recently, what he thinks of the work being done.

I am, Dear Sir,

Yours Respectfully,

S. R. McVitty

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Pedley,

In accordance with instructions I visited the Mount Elgin Institute on June 26th.

I looked carefully over the new wings on the main building and found everything in good order and am satisfied that a good job has been made. All the buildings and surroundings are in a splendid condition and are a credit to the Department and to the management of the school.

There are a few matters in connection with the Institute which I wish to bring to your attention. Some months ago the Hobbs Hardware Company supplied some glass for the school and the account was forwarded to the Department. In the meantime the firm drew at sight on the Principal and he honoured the draft. When the cheque was drawn by the Department it was sent to the firm and returned by them, but up to the present time Mr. McVitty has not been reimbursed. He should be paid this money as it is a legitimate charge against the Department.

Ottawa, July 16, 1913.
There has been considerable correspondence also in regard to the boiler. You will recollect that Mr. McVitty was instructed to purchase a boiler for the laundry from Messrs. George White and Sons. This firm, however, did not have a suitable boiler in stock and advised him to go to Messrs. E. Leonard and Sons. As the matter was extremely urgent Mr. McVitty made the purchase from the last mentioned firm without authority from the Department. Up to the present time the Department has not paid the account and has informed Mr. McVitty that he will have to settle with the firm in question. In connection with this matter and that of certain materials for repairs to the Principal's residence, to which I shall refer later on in this report, I think Mr. McVitty has had a good lesson and that in future he will not make any purchases or incur any expenditure of this kind without the express authority of the Department and I would recommend that the boiler be paid for. There is no question as to the reasonableness of the price.

Mr. McVitty also incurred an expenditure of some $600.00 in flooring, painting and papering the Principal's residence and flooring the officers' dining room. These rooms were floored in soft wood before and the oak flooring put in by the Principal has added greatly to their appearance and will last for years. There is no doubt that the
the repairs made by Mr. McVitty were quite necessary, but he again made the mistake of doing this work without getting authority.

The painting of the stables so far as it has been done has added very greatly to their appearance and will also be a protection against the weather.

I may add that the Methodist Missionary Society spent approximately $1600.00 in new furnishings for the Principal's residence and it was quite natural, therefore, that the general appearance of the rooms should be in keeping with the furniture.

I would recommend also that the accounts in connection with the residence be paid and also for the material for the painting of the barns.

I was very much impressed with the great improvement in the management of this school since Mr. McVitty took charge. There is no doubt that he is an able manager and performing a useful work for the Department in the education of the Indian children attending the Institute. Their farm is one of the best in the province and, as I said before, the buildings and surroundings generally are a credit to all concerned.

Dear Sir:

Re our terrible fire of Sunday, permit me to make the following report:

1. The fire was started by little Isaiah Muskrat letting off a firecracker under a pile of straw. (Some one had given the pupils fire crackers on Friday, at our picnic). He had it in a little tin can, and thought he was hiding where no one would see him. I was at home myself, and every officer was right here. We saw the fire inside ten minutes after it started. Hundreds of people, including almost every Indian in the neighbourhood, were with us in a very short time. The utmost we could do was to save a couple of horses, and a few other animals. We lost about twenty-five head in all, including a very valuable horse.

Our greatest effort was to save the annex and main building. We did so by beating the fire back from the woodshed and laundry, both of which were on fire several times.

I never saw men work harder than the Indians did until every bucket of water was exhausted. We also had a
small chemical engine, which we purchased some time ago. It proved of great service in beating the fire out of the laundry and wood shed roof, and a great pile of wood stored in the yard near the shed.

So great was the danger to the main buildings at times that the consensus of opinion led us to remove a large part of the contents out into the lawn, but, at the most crucial moment the wind veered from the East almost due North, and this, of course threw the flames in the opposite direction, and so our main building, annex, and laundry are practically unhurt, and school is going on as usual.

The children feel very sorry for what has occurred, (I have sought in every way to impress them with the seriousness of it), and were rejoiced to learn this morning that we hope to re-build our barns right away. They love the animals, especially the cows. I was much touched with the pleading of some boys not to sell the cows. They knew them every one by name, and some boys risked their lives in getting a few out of the burning buildings. The greater part of the cows had just come up to the barns for milking, but were not tied up, so they escaped.

Of course all our implements, machinery, and tools, also harness, hay, straw, and about 1000 bus. of grain were destroyed.

Construction of Reinforced Concrete Pavements and Roadways

By H. S. Doyle

Within less than a decade steel has received recognition as an important factor in the construction of country roads and city pavements. Steel constantly finds its way to the front ranks of new uses, and none the least of these is the road builder. In the United States and highways, combining with concrete, steel, in the form of drawn wire, is rapidly taking a place in the engineering programme which contemplates a greater permanence to the already determined solidity of Portland cement. The main advantage promised by reinforced concrete over ordinary concrete lies in the fact that it can be laid at an average price of $1.10 to $1.25 per square yard. Excluding the most of maintenance, which is lower for concrete than for any other type, and assuming the life of all types of permanent pavements to be the same, a saving in the first cost can be obtained by the use of reinforced concrete that could be used to pay for at least 50 percent of the total replacement cost when such replacement becomes necessary. Thus, at 4 percent compound interest for twenty years, will amount to the original cost of the pavement, or in other words, the cost of a new pavement. Although the cheapest and best of other types, the original cost of the latter will construct a high class reinforced concrete pavement and replace it at the end of twenty years.

The comparative cost of various types of pavement in a number of American cities according to the best available data is contained in the following table. The showing is very much to the advantage of concrete pavements. The proper thickness for a pavement depends largely upon the amount and kind of traffic it will be required to carry. Although the condition of the foundation and the amount and position of the reinforcement used may require a certain minimum thickness, it will generally be advisable to make a total thickness of six inches on residential streets, and seven inches on business streets. In any case, however, depending on the type of pavement the wearing course should be at least one and one-half inches thick. These figures are considered good practice, but it should be remembered that they do not allow for a sufficient amount of reinforcement.

For reinforcing concrete pavement a woven wire reinforcement is the best that can be used. In order to form such an economical construction, using loose bars, it would be necessary to space them at a distance which would not give a satisfactory distribution over the steel. Small wires spaced from eight to ten inches or more apart cannot be used, since they would result in comparison with a woven wire reinforcement having an equal and close spacing of the members. Therefore, the use of a reinforced concrete pavement of gold drawn wire properly tested to give uniform results. It has a minimum ultimate breaking strength of 85,000 pounds per square inch, and is made up of solid or stranded longitudinal members properly spaced by means of diagonal cross wires so arranged as to form a series of triangles between each longitudinal and cross member. The longitudinal members are invariably spaced four inches apart, the cross wires either two inches or four inches apart, thus providing either a 2-inch or 4-inch triangle. Longitudinal members and cross wires are used in order to provide the cross-sectional areas of steel required to meet the requirements of the job.

Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer
The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune,
Or to take arms against a sea of troubles,
And by opposing end them? To die, to sleep—
No more; and by a sleep to say we end
The heartache and the thousand natural shocks
That flesh is heir to? 'Tis a consummation
Devoutly to be wished. To die, to sleep—
To sleep, perchance to dream: ay, there's the rub;
For in that sleep of death what dreams may come
When we have shuffled off this mortal coil,
Must give us pause: there's the respect
That makes calamity of so long life:
For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
The oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely,
The pangs of despised love, the law's delay,
The insolence of office and the spurns
That patient merit of the unworthy takes,
When he himself might his quietus make
With a bare bodkin? Who would fardels bear,
To grunt and sweat under a weary life,
But that the dread of something after death,
The undiscovered country from whose bourn
No traveller returns, puzzles the will
And makes us rather bear those ills we have
Than fly to others that we know not of?
Thus conscience does make cowards of us all,
And thus the native hue of resolution
Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought,
And enterprises of great pith and moment
With this regard their currents turn awry,
And lose the name of action.

It would change the length of every member in the truss.

Knowing just how urgently these buildings are required, we sincerely hope that you will not insist on the amended details referred to being complied with. Dear Mr. Witty,

Yesterday I made an examination of the kitchen sinks and the drainage therefrom as there were complaints of not only foul odors from them but also of sewage backing up and seeping through the kitchen floor. Upon being dug up the drain proves to be composed of ordinary field tiles which allow the sewage to escape. As there is no provision for arresting grease and as the pupils are possibly more careless than adults would be in the matter of allowing solid materials to reach the drain, it soon becomes blocked when it has to be dug up.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6206, file 468-5, part 3)
This is very unsanitary and cannot be too strongly condemned.

The tiles should at once be replaced with impervious soil pipe, there should be a grease trap and provision should be made for cleaning out the drain if it does become blocked.

I neglected to say that it was to the sinks in Mount Elgin Institute to which this letter refers.

Yours very truly,

W.H. Woods.
Ottawa, November 24, 1915.

The material used should be vitrified salt glazed drain tile laid in cement joints cemented full hub and watertight, and the cost to be as economical as possible for first class work.

Attention of Prin. Mr. S. R. McVitty,

Dear Sir:

On March 7th, we had our man make a thorough inspection of the electric wiring of the main building of the Institute, as per your instructions. We also had the Hydro Electric Inspector go over the building, as we did not like to take all the responsibility on ourselves, a copy of his report you will find attached.

Our man reports that the wiring is in a bad condition, and not at all safe. The joints are not soldered nor properly taped, and are very poorly made. The wires are not properly insulated, and run through the wood joice, without Porcelain tubes, also the wire is very old, and the rubber insulation dry, and hard. The wires are not properly fastened with knobs, and are lying on the wood lath. Also at the Panel the wires are only stuck in the lugs loose, where they should be soldered in.

This is very dangerous, and is apt to cause a fire at any time, also the style of wiring is not good, as both wires of the circuit should run direct to the distribution centre, which it does not. This is very bad practice.

We find the wiring in the new wing of the main building in very good condition, and consider same perfectly safe.

Hoping that our report will be satisfactory to all parties concerned, and that we may be favored with your valued order, of putting the wiring in your building in first class condition, we remain,

Yours Truly,

INGRAM & DAVEY, Limited.

MOUNT ELGIN INDUSTRIAL FARM

S. R. McVITTY, SUPERINTENDENT

Muncey, Ont., January 16th, 1917.

Dear Sir,

During the winter weather we are under necessity of drying all clothes by the air underclothing, as the rafters in the laundry room are dormitories, as we have no dryer room in building.

We have a press of about people to be well clothed and kept clean, and our nurse is very grateful that she has now the drying clothes in at the best of times. Besides it is well-nigh impossible to get her to do any work as it ought to be before using.

I find a "Drier" built by Laundry people to very expensive, and think if we had the metal flat, that is better, galvanized iron for lining, and some twisted pipe for heating, also some light brick on which to put the clothes carried in an oven, as could be bought for $100.00 build a very suitable drier, which, if properly built in the proper way would cost us nothing.

I will be glad to hear from you as to what you think of this proposal, and if you can give me any advice, as there are some points that seem rather difficult.

Yours respectfully,

S. R. McVitty

Dear Mr. Ogilvie—

Since my visit to Ottawa, I have been thinking and planning for our water supply almost night and day. It is so important that we do the right thing.

I was down in the ram pit today, and it occurred to me that it might be quite possible to put a small gasoline engine there, and pump the waste water from the rams. There is an extra pipe from the building. If the two large tanks in the attic could be kept full all the time, we could get along splendidly. (One of these tanks is leaking, so out of use.) The surplus, or waste water from the rams would be quite sufficient. Possibly we would need to deepen the catch basins, and extend the drains into the bush.

We have a deep tank in the laundry yard at present, which holds 3000 gals., but we pump it out in a very short time. It makes me suspicious about storage.

Memorandum

Mr. Scott,

An application has recently been made for new water tanks for the Mount Elgin Institute, the old ones having become useless through corrosion from length of service, the water escaping having caused considerable damage to the wall of room below. Before authorizing new tanks, the Principal has been requested to have an estimate prepared showing the cost of providing similar tanks to replace the old ones.

The water service at the school is very unsatisfactory as now provided, as they are entirely dependent in the building for a supply from tanks erected on the attic floor and piped to the fixtures on several floors and which, whilst supplying their immediate requirements, does not afford any fire protection.
The existing water supply is now obtained from hydraulic pressure, the water being gathered into storage basins and conducted to hydraulic rams which force the water into the tanks in the attic. With this system, about one gallon out of every twenty passing through the hydraulic engine, reaches the building, the balance providing the motive power for elevating the water to the tanks.

An adequate supply of water for all purposes from the present source of supply, can be provided by either of two methods.

(1.) Depending on the present equipment up to its capacity and pumping the additional amount required direct into tanks from well near building.

(2.) By diverting a portion of the water from gathering-basins by gravitation to reservoir near building and elevating by power-pump into tanks in building or into pneumatic tanks.

The first plan will be the less costly to install, but whilst providing a satisfactory supply of water for the building, does not provide fire-protection.
The second plan will provide better water, (as there is less danger from surface contamination) and in sufficient quantities for their purposes, including fire-protection, as with an ample reservoir with exterior hydrants and interior stand pipes with power pump system, an adequate protection from fire would be obtained.

This would also be possible by the use of the pneumatic tank system, but to a lesser degree depending on its capacity.

The estimated cost of the first plan would be £1200.00 to £1500.00.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Your favour of the 18th inst. is before me. Very many thanks for prompt assistance rendered us in the hour of danger and difficulty.

We are getting along splendidly carrying out authorized improvements as rapidly as possible.

Have read over Mr. Ogilvie's memorandum very carefully, and feel satisfied that proposition No. 1 would not meet the needs of the case. A well would be quite useless in drought of Summer, even for domestic purposes; not to speak of fire. We would pump it dry in a day.

On Saturday, our Head Teacher, mechanic, and myself made a most careful examination of the whole source of water supply. We are fully satisfied that an abundance of pure water can be obtained by—

1. Lifting, and cleaning out the drains already laid, but which are now choked with quick sand.

2. Extending feeders to these drains, and possibly placing a larger tile in mains, and using tile now in use to extend drains.

There is a little ridge or embankment between the source of water, and the catch basin which feeds the runs. The tile through this part is down about 10', and is so filled with sand as to divert the water in another direction. These drains would serve the two-fold purpose of gathering the water, and draining the farm at the same time.

3. There will also need to be a suitable culvert laid, to convey water from these cuttings to reservoir in the yard.

Dear Sir:

On July 27th last you wrote the Rev. S. R. McVitty,
Pr. Mt. Elgin Institute, Muncey, Ontario regarding our bill,
which included the contract for wiring the institute, amount-
ing to Four Hundred and Fifty ($450.00) Dollars, together with
extras amounting to $166.24. Total amount of our claim
$616.24.

Principal McVitty replied to this letter on July
31st last stating that the Hydro Inspector had made demands
on us which we had not anticipated, and in view of these facts
he hoped the Department would give us a generous settlement.
After this recommendation we have been expecting your cheque
ever since, and in case further information is required regard-
ing the extras we will try and explain as fully as possible how
we arrive at this amount.

In the first place about March 2nd, 1916 we received
from Principal McVitty a request to send a man down to look
over the building in order that this work could be gone into
thoroughly. We suggested that we take the local Hydro Inspector
with us, believing that we could give you a more accurate
report. We did this, and enclose you a copy of his report. On
January 29th we received from Principal McVitty a copy of a
Telegram signed J. D. McLean, as follows:

Electric wire Muncey Institute to be #12 wire in
concealed conduit. Exposed work will not be permitted. You
or your assistant to inspect work without charge. Final inspect-
ion to be made by Hydro Electric Inspector, who must pass same
before payment. Please note there was no specification to work
to. You simply asked for estimate for the repairing of the
wiring in the main building. We therefore had to leave it with
our man and the inspector as to what was to be done.
On April 13th, 1917 we sent you our figures as follows: We will rewire this building all in conduit for the sum of $450.00, or we will rewire the basement in conduit and wire the upper floors in knob and tube for the sum of $325.00. This work to be done to comply with the Hydro Electric Inspector and with first class workmanship and number one material used throughout.

In your letter to Principal McVitty under date of May 9, 1916 you mention in awarding Ingram & Davey, Ltd., the tender for this work at $450.00 to be done in conduit. You state, this price is to cover all work necessary in the installation, including all cutting and repairs to walls, ceilings, floors, decorations, etc complete. On April 28th however we received a copy of your letter of April 28th to Pr. McVitty stating no action could be taken however until an estimate had been submitted for all repair work necessary in connection with this installation, and the placing again of the building in a complete state. We replied to this letter on May 2nd, copy of this letter you have, and part of it is as follows:

In reply would say we know of no extra work in connection with our part of the work. We included in our estimate the taking up and laying down again all floors, where it was necessary to lift them for the wiring. Therefore our figure includes fully the taking up of all floors, and replacing them as before, and we know of no extra work that would be likely to turn up during the progress of this work.

We therefore feel that you can advise the Government that our price included everything in connection with the installation. We therefore wish to point out however that should any new fixtures be required of course that would be additional, but we understood from our Mr. Swackhammer who was in charge of the work that you intended to use your present fixtures.

In the first place we wish to draw your attention to the local inspectors report. You will please note nothing is mentioned about fixtures and the present wire used.
with same, and neither our man or the inspector took into consideration this part of the work. They were called to report on the wiring, and our price was based on this report. After the wiring was done the inspector refused to allow us to use the present old code wire for the fixtures, and ordered our man to put in new material.

Here is where our man in charge of the work made a mistake, when he did not stop and have it thoroughly understood that this part of the work was not included in the Tender. This man was not the man who figured the work, but was the man in charge of the work on the building. He was told the fixtures in the building at that time were of no use, and he went right on and put in the proper new material, which was made up mostly of new lamp cord, sockets, insulating joints, R. L. Balls chain and labor to put these up, as we understood the fixtures for the main building and basement comprised mostly cord drops, and this was what the material was used for, and bill for same we sent you, and are again attaching a separate bill for the extras, showing the different items used for this purpose.

Regarding the Panel Board, the inspector thought the old one would do, but it was found out during the work that it would not answer, as Mr. McVitty knows. In making up the new bill for extras we have included the labor and board separate with the work of installing the Panel Board. You will therefore see the balance of the extras are not a big item.

In the first place the contract was altogether too low, and if you had other figures we feel sure you will find that we took the job altogether too cheap. However, this is our loss, and we are not asking anything more on the contract, but we do ask to be paid for the extra work done on which we did not figure. Even with the contract and extras combined the whole job is only a little over six hundred ($600.00) Dollars, and we assure you this is very low, and would not leave us any profit at the full price.
We trust you will take this up with the Department at once and trust they will see their way to pay our claim in full at once. This work has been done many months, and in addition to the amount the interest on this amount would be quite an item, which naturally makes it all the worse.

In addition we paid the Railway charges and also the inspectors' time several times in order to give you a thorough report and to see it was done properly, for which no charge was made by us.

Trusting you will give this your immediate attention we beg to remain.

Dear Mr. Scott:

We have just about completed our water system. I am sending you, under separate cover, sketch showing extent and character of work done. Everything has been purchased save gasoline engine, and I would greatly like the consent of the Department to use our present engine as indicated, and apply the price of a four horse engine, on the purchase of a Delco Lighting System to be used in the Main Building.

The system will cost $600.00 installed. We will pay the $300.00 out of school funds. To install, we will simply connect at switch entering the Main Building, and will not disturb wiring in any possible way. We would use present dynamo for street and barns and engine for pumping water.

My reasons for suggesting this change are as follows:

1. During the dark days we need a few lights in lower kitchen, halls, and girls' playroom all the time. This means lighting and carrying around of lamps by the pupils.

2. So need a few lights in main halls all night. This means lamps, matches, etc.

3. There are times, especially in cold weather, when it is difficult to get the gas engine started promptly in the morning. This, again, means running for lamps, etc., and once in a while the engine will stop, belt slip, or some other little thing happen when pupils are coming in to supper, and, again, it is

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6206, file 468-5, part 3)
Tamps, matches, etc.

All this greatly increases the danger of fire. In matters of fire in a building of this kind the great concern must always be prevention.

1. To run the big engine just for a few lights is too expensive.
2. Our present dynamo is 110 volt; and this would mean a very large and expensive battery, if we attempted that solution. Besides, the Dynamo has been running steadily about eight years, and of course will soon show effect of wear.

This all brings me back to the purchase of Dolco plant as the best and easiest solution. It is fully guaranteed, will be installed on free trial, will give all lights necessary for Main Building. It's storage battery provides 20 lights for 16 hours - more than we would ever need. It will cost about one-half for running expense. It will greatly reduce risk of fires by doing away entirely with matches and lamps. It will not cost the Department any more than to purchase engine for pumping. We will provide the extra $300.00

I know of several Dolco plants lighting farm premises, and, in every case it is giving best of satisfaction. They use a low voltage lamp, but offer to exchange lamp for lamp with us.

Our large engine would run barn lights from 7 to 8 am., and from 3 to 6 pm., and at same time pump all water needed.

I hope I have made the matter sufficiently clear, and that the Department will approve of the suggestion, and, at least, permit a two weeks trial pf plant, as suggested by the Dolco people.

Pleased to say our total expenditure for water system will not exceed amount appropriated.

I am, Dear Mr. Scott,

Yours very sincerely,

Dear Sir,

I regret to report that when the big ice came in the river at Belleville, your way, it swept away practically every house I knew on our line, flotsam threw up tons upon tons of debris on our farms, fences, etc. This we have been fighting off for days. The fences will have to be put up before the cattle get out, as all our wheat and spring crops turned to dust, yet we will of course do the building which will cost us several hundred dollars but much work the Dep.
Ottawa, April 12, 1918.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant, in which you report that when the big ice jam in the river at Dalhousie gave way it swept away practically every rod of fence on the river flats in connection with the Mount Elgin Institute and state that you will do the building of the fences, but must ask the Department for a grant for material.

In reply I beg to say that you may expend the amounts mentioned by you for the necessary posts and wire for rebuilding the fences, viz., $100.00 for posts and $200.00 for the wire.

Your obedient servant,

Now an alternative proposition would be to let the play house stand over for a time, and when erected make it a play room downstairs, and an assembly room upstairs (a thing we greatly need) and expend about $2000.00 on the present work shop, which expenditure would include new foundation, flooring, siding inside and out, (dogs can run through it now, and the snow blows over material and tools) new windows and doors, reshingling of the roof and painting of the entire building. Dear Sir:

Rev. Mr. Perrier has given us several days at Mount Elgin, and we have gone carefully into matters concerning the school. This school has to serve all the Methodist Indian children, and many others in the two provinces, so far as a better education is concerned, and the fact that we are compelled to turn children away is proof that the Indian is at least appreciating our work.

Now we have not asked the Department for any considerable amount for about six years, and our need of a work shop and boys' play house is so great as to be imperative.

Dear Sir:

Rev. Mr. Perrier has given us several days at Mount Elgin, and we have gone carefully into matters concerning the school. We both feel that there must be a very considerable expenditure on the part of the church for house equipment, farm implements, carpenter tools and additional breeding stock. A total of say $5000.00. We have been doing without things for several years, and want so far as we are concerned to bring everything right up to date.

This school has to serve all the Methodist Indian children, and many others in the two provinces, so far as a better education is concerned, and the fact that we are compelled to turn children away is proof that the Indian is at least appreciating our work.

Now we have not asked the Department for any considerable amount for about six years, and our need of a work shop and boys play house is so great as to be imperative.

November 10th, 1920.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Sir James Lougheed -

The Mount Elgin Industrial school, situated at Muncey, Ont., is the property of the Department. I may state that some of the Indian bands of Ontario contributed towards the cost of erecting the original building. This school serves the Methodist children of the Provinces of Ontario and Quebec as well as some others. It is a very excellent school, one of the best conducted in the country.

The principal has asked for the erection of a combined workshop and play-house at an approximate cost of $10,000.00, or as an alternative proposition an expenditure of about $2,000.00 on their present workshop, which would provide for a new foundation, flooring and siding inside and out.

While I recognize the great need of the combined workshop and play-house, I do not consider this an opportune time to undertake any extensive building. I am, however, disposed to comply with the principal's request and make the necessary repairs to the present workshop. The building is a splendid frame and if properly repaired now would serve its purpose for many years. The principal, Mr. McVitty, is a thoroughly practical man and I feel confident that the repairs, if authorized, would be carried out in a most satisfactory manner. I would, therefore, ask for your authority for the expenditure of the amount above mentioned, payment to be made from the school appropriation for the current year.

Deputy Superintendent General.
