As the supply of water from the south hydraulic ram has failed, it is necessary to use the water from the west hydraulic ram for drinking and culinary purposes. This supply is not adequate for all purposes, and it cannot be safely increased by the water in the stock watering tanks. The water in these tanks, though apparently excellent, I do not think that it would be safe to mix it with the water from the hydraulic rams. I would, therefore, respectfully recommend that a well be sunk in the school yard and the water from it used to supplement the supply from the west.

Globe Wood Washer
30" and 40" Diameter

Size
The inner cylinder shall be inches in diameter by inches in length and shall have doors and partitions, hinges, catches and hoops.

Cylinder
Shall have heads and staves of Fir, with ribs of Maple. Staves cut from 1\(\frac{1}{2}\) inch stock shall be nailed to heads cut from 2-inch stock. Shall be three large lifting ribs, 2\(\frac{1}{2}\) inches thick by 4 inches deep; also a 2\(\frac{3}{8}\) x 2\(\frac{5}{8}\) inch rib at front end back of each opening subjected to heavy strain. Door shall rest 15\(\frac{1}{2}\) inches. Door catches shall be of brass. Hinges shall be wide and heavy, and shall rest bottom of door opening and on brass plates on front door rib. Catches shall have wide lips. Cylinders shall be handled with wide and heavy hoops, fastened to the staves by means of brass screws.

Tub
Shall be constructed of Fir with staves cut from 1\(\frac{1}{2}\) inch stock tongued and grooved and joined to fit over heads cut from 2-inch stock, to which they shall be nailed. A galvanized iron sliding door shall operate in grooves provided on adjustable encircling bands or hoops. Brass apron shall be fitted at bottom of door opening to protect the staves.

Iron Frames
The entire weight of cylinder and tub shall rest on cast-iron frames of neat design, to which the driving mechanism shall be attached. Frames shall be solid one-piece castings and be bolted to tub heads.

Inlet and Outlet
Located in the center bottom of tub shall be a combination cast-iron flange tee through which the steam and water shall enter and waste water be discharged. Steam shall enter washer through an annular steam passage cored in the tee without coming in direct contact with the wood or linen. Connected with the flange tee shall be an outlet pipe on the end of which a 3-inch quick opening valve of the hollow taper plug type shall be fitted.

Trunnions and Bearings
Cast-iron trunnions shall be attached to cylinder heads by means of brass-covered bolts and inside of cylinder heads shall be fitted with two brass trunion rings. The journals of trunnions shall operate in babitted bearings on the cast-iron frames.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

In accord with official letter No. I5500I-5C dated August 13th, we have proceeded to make certain repairs to the buildings at this school. I regret to report that we found much more needed than we had anticipated. Outside stairs leading to the Senior school room, also the one leading to the Officer's dining room are quite unsafe and will have to be replaced by new ones. Several window and door arches have loose bricks, and the foundation of the upstairs pantry is bulging out and must be replaced. Some plumbing is needed and quite a bit of eavestroughing.

We found wire on door and window screens old and broken. Practically the whole building has had to be done over. We deemed this absolutely necessary owing to a serious epidemic of typhoid in vicinity. We want to make every portion of the building nearly fly proof as possible. There are 100 typhoid patients in the Hospital for the Insane at London at the present time, and many deaths. So we are having all water tested before the return of pupils September 1st.

A letter from Mr. Ferrier informs me that he and Dr. Manning laid before you our request for a primary school building at Muncey, and that you are giving the matter favorable consideration. The need is very great. I could mention a large number of children in this part of Ontario who are really neglected. Several of them children of ex-service men. We are overcrowded here now, and cannot admit anymore.

Mr. Abraham has already taken or sent up to the Soo about fifteen pupils, who really should be under our care. It is a long way to send them, and cuts them off from their own people.

Mr. Ferrier's estimate of $75,000.00 is too high. Building is much cheaper, and I am quite sure a suitable building could be erected for $40,000.00. We do not need a palace, but comfortable suitable quarters. The superintendency could be carried on from this office, without additional expense, and the resources of our farm and farm equipment would be available at first cost.

Dear Sir:

About three years ago the tower on this school was struck by lightning and seriously damaged. At that time I pointed out to the Department the advisability of having the metal ornaments on top of each of the three towers grounded by suitable wire. No steps were taken to do so. This summer a prominent builder was visiting us and was amazed that we should allow a day to pass without having ground wires attached. We did not in any way draw his attention to the matter.

On Wednesday night last, a furious electric storm swept over this District. The main tower was struck and quite shattered. This took place in the night. Fortunately it did not catch fire, else the building would undoubtedly have been destroyed and possibly some lives lost.

We notified the Insurance Company; Repairs should be made soon as possible, and most assuredly the wiring should be done at earliest possible moment.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

September 23, 1922.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,-

The Manager of the Norwich Union Fire Insurance Society has written to me regarding the building used as an industrial and residential school by your Department situated on the Mount Elgin Industrial Farm, Township of Caradoc, County of Middlesex. I understand that this building has been struck by lightning and the Manager suggests that the building should be equipped with a lightning rod.

The rodding of buildings for protection against lightning has received attention of this Department for some time, and we are fully convinced of the adequacy of the protection thus afforded.

The loss of farm buildings in the province of Ontario during the last two or three years has been a very serious drain upon the agricultural portion of the community. So far as the insurance people are concerned their rate is varied to meet the hazard so that it is not a material consideration from their standpoint what the losses are. There is, however, the loss to the community from the needless destruction of property and the loss to the individual over and above the insurance because, as a rule, farm buildings are inadequately insured.

I thought I would write you regarding the matter in order that if you are considering the question you might be able to have this building more completely protected.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Superintendent of Insurance.

Dear Dr. Scott:

Re Orphanage at Muncey.—When in your office on Tuesday, you will remember we discussed the matter of some provision being made for orphan Indian children in the Province of Ontario. In this connection, I intend to place before our General Board of Missions the advisability of a building being constructed on the Muncey Institute property, believing that such an institution could be managed much more economically by the staff of that Institute than by any other provision that might be made at present. The overhead charges for the managing of such an institution would be largely met by its being connected with, and under the management of the Principal of, the Muncey Institute.

I am taking this course, believing that such a proposition would meet with the approbation of the Department of Indian Affairs. If there are any objections that could be offered to this plan, would you kindly favor me with the same. Such would prevent any wrong impression being conveyed to our General Board of Missions.

RE MUNCEY, ONTARIO
PRIMARY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Strong representations have been made to the Board of Missions of the Methodist Church relative to the desirability of providing on the Muncey Reserve a Primary Residential School for Indian children.

There are many children on the Indian Reserves in Ontario, who are too young to attend the ordinary residential schools, for whose education and care no provision has been made. Some of these are children of deceased soldiers.

When the matter of providing such a residential school was under consideration by our Board of Missions at its recent session, a resolution was passed endorsing this proposal and urging upon the Department of Indian Affairs the necessity of establishing such a school at Muncey as soon as possible.

I trust that this matter will receive the favorable consideration of the Government and that an appropriation of from $35,000 to $50,000 will be made at the next session of Parliament to erect such a school.

Dear Dr. Scott:

In reply to personal letter of October 10th, re holidays, permit me to say that the practice of two months' holidays at this school started during the stress of war time. I drew your attention to it, then when in Ottawa you simply nodded assent, and it has continued since then.

Holidays start July 1st and end August 31st. Children whose parents need them go home, others remain here and are paid wages, girls of any size $30 per month and boys $30 to $40 according to size.

The arrangement is most pleasing to the Indians but expensive to us. July and August are haying and harvest. There will be a great row if it is changed. The Six Nation spirit has permeated our entire constituency and our Indians are spoiling for a contest, especially on points of law.

I am, Dear Dr. Scott,

Yours very sincerely,

S. R. McVitty

Dear Sir:

Having just returned from a visit to the Muncey Institute, I feel it necessary to draw the attention of the Department to the heating plant, which I found very inadequate to keep the buildings comfortable, and some parts of them even habitable, during the cold weather that prevailed while I was there.

There are three hard coal furnaces heating water for the main building. Two of these were in the building before the two new wings were built, and the Principal informs me that they did very good work for what was expected of them at that time. When the new wings were built the one on the North end had a furnace installed to heat the new portion. The South wing was plumbed up and connected with the two furnaces that originally heated the older part of the building. The result is that during cold weather and high winds the portions of the building where the wind strikes are not even habitable. During the time I was there the Principal's private rooms could not be used, and the Principal's wife informed me that ever since the South wing was built the only place she had where she could sit in comfort was the office, beside the stove that has been installed there.

Pennsylvania coal is being burned in the Institute and all that the furnaces will take was crowded into them during the time I was there, and I am free to say that I discovered it is absolutely impossible to heat the buildings. I could make recommendations as to what could be done to ensure proper heating, but as it is near Ottawa, I think it would be well to send an expert to look over the whole situation and let him suggest the best solution for the entire problem of heating.

A system of lockers in the Boys' Playroom, in which to keep school clothes in order that they may change before going into the classroom, is a necessity. - Estimated cost about a couple of hundred dollars.

A portion of the staff kitchen and pantry is a small
addition to the rear of the building and is cracked from the main building and bricks and stones are tumbling out of the end of it. It should be pulled down and a larger addition built in its place. This larger addition might comprise a pantry and staff dining-room. If this were done, the present staff dining-room could be used for a staff sitting-room, which they are without at present. - Estimated cost about $1,000.

A new three-even range is required in the pupils' kitchen. - Estimated cost about $600.00

Another matter that should receive the attention of the Department is the condition of the road just at the point where the School farm and the Reserve meet. There is a sharp turn there, which is very dangerous, the grade being very high and the road being narrow, and at the present time covered with slush. There is a great danger of autos and rigs slipping off into the ditch. It might be well for the Department to communicate with your Agent regarding the matter. The estimated cost would be about $300.00.

The old building that is used for two dwellings, hospital quarters and one class-room should be renovated, and one end of it, where a family now dwells, could be added to the hospital accommodation. This would give ample room for all the sick. When I was there a number were ill with the "flu". It would have been better if some of the worst cases could have been isolated from the others. I suggest this change inasmuch as the Agent is occupying one end of the building, and I understand the Department is contemplating building a home for the Agent in the village of Muncey. When this move takes place, the renovation and changes could be made. - Estimated cost about $250.00.

If it were possible, I would like to have in the supplementary estimates an item of about $5,000.00 for Muncey.

There are a number of improvements that can be made by new furniture and new machinery on the farm, which have been postponed during the last few years on account of high prices. I feel sure that the Management is prepared to spend between $3,000.00 and $4,000.00 in this direction, and I hope that the Department will be able to provide the above sum, so that a thorough job may be made of the heating plant.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,

The Mount Elgin Indian Residential School at Muncey Sends Greeting:

We are pleased to be able to inform you that our attendance is larger, our health better than ever before. Our promotion and High School Entrance Examinations are fully equal to those of neighboring "White Schools."

The Government and the Church are showing us every consideration, and have already planned large improvements for next year, but what fills our hearts with hope is the really marvelous awakening of the Indian people themselves to the advantages of a higher and better education. Many Indians have seen and felt this for years. All seem to see it now. Several boys who ran away from school years ago have recently returned of their own accord, and are earnestly seeking an education.

The time has come for a real advance; but there must be perfect understanding and agreement as to methods. We have decided therefore to hold a Conference on Indian Education at this school on Thursday, June 28th, commencing at 10 o'clock a.m.

We hope to have a representative each from the Government and the Church, and most cordially invite each Indian Council in Ontario and Quebec to send a delegate, a forward-looking man, who knows what his people want. We will entertain these delegates well, show them the school as it is, and then sit down together and plan how to make it better.

On Friday, 29th June, we will hold a great School picnic on the School grounds. There will be refreshment booths, games, speeches, community singing, band music, and lots of other good things. Just one whole day of feasting and fun. At its close pupils can go home for Summer holidays.

All "Old Pupils" are especially invited. Come and meet your school friends of other days.

Yours for better times,

S. R. McVITTY, Principal

Dear Sir—In reply to Official Letter No 155001-5 of 3rd inst., re heating plant at this school, permit me to say that we are ever willing to do the best we can with the facilities we have and hope for better, but in the matter of heating it is best the Dep. should know that under no circumstance will we accept the responsibility of carrying on another winter under present conditions.

We did every thing possible last Fall to secure good hard coal as of other years. (see your letter of Oct. 11th 22 which was the best you could do for us and brought no results). It was absolutely impossible to get it. We did secure two cars of semi-hard rubbish for which we paid $7.00 per ton cash, and now we cannot get even that and have been compelled to accept a car of soft coal at $15.00 in car lot. The result of it all is that with present furnace capacity driven to its very utmost, we could not keep the building above freezing point. We have been forced therefore, to erect stoves in different parts of the building, some of which are attached to ventilating flues into which timbers protrude. The danger of fire is so great that I have made a personal inspection of the entire building last thing almost every night this winter.

We have in all about sixty cases of "flu", a large number have developed pneumonia. Some no doubt as result of the coldness of their dormitories. A few are in the hospital, and some boys of over 15 years have been moved to the south side and are being nursed in same ward with girls of similar age.

I hereto report that in Wednesday, 28th instant, in accordance with your instructions, I made an inspection of the heating system at the Mount Alvin Institute.

The building is heated at present by a hot water heating system in which three Jurney-Oxford cast iron sectional boilers are used. Two of the boilers used in the main building are located at one end, and the third is located in the addition, and, owing to the great length of pipe it is impossible to satisfactorily heat the institution. In many of the rooms the temperature cannot be kept above the freezing point. I may say that during my visit yesterday, the weather was very cold with a strong wind blowing and I found practically the entire building very uncomfortable, although good fires were being kept in the heating boilers.

For an institution of this kind hot water is not the most satisfactory and economical system of heating. The only way to provide this building with an adequate heating system would be to convert the present hot water system into a low pressure steam system. In doing so, all of the existing radiators and most of the piping could be used. It would be necessary, however, to provide a new boiler room in the center to the rear of the main building, and install a steam boiler. A new chimney would also be required as the existing ones are altogether too small to provide the necessary draft for the boiler.

With reference to the boiler-room, I would say that the institution are rather cramped for accommodation in the way of staff living rooms and suitable sleeping quarters for Indians who visit and remain over night at the institution. If the new boiler room was erected, the additional accommodation could be very economically provided over the boiler room.

The estimated cost of placing in this building a satisfactory system of steam heating would be approximately $1000.
The Reverend Principal has advised me that unless some arrangement is made to heat the building next winter, it will be impossible for him to keep his staff, also that there has been considerable sickness at the institution during this winter which was caused by the present unsatisfactory heating system.

Think what that means—no chance of mix ups. No getting of a section up on the base, only to find out it's wrong.

You can't go wrong on our Twin Boiler. The twins are nipple connected at top and sides and joined at the rear with a 3 inch pipe. See Page 10.

Erection starts with the front sections. A seal-tight-strip goes over the space between the sections on the front and back, making a finished air-tight job.

The sections are twins and so are the grates. Although the grate surface is 50 inches wide, no single grate is longer than 24 inches.

Think what that means in ease of handling, ease of set up and ease of replacement.
The Economy

Mules, boilers and automobiles are a good bit alike. They each have their balky points. For example; many an auto maker who had a wonderful engine of a certain given cylinder bore, when he increased it, the power developed was not in proportion.

The old law of diminishing ratios started in upsetting things.

There is a point where a boiler can be too large, as well as too small, to be economical. Mr. Burnham has been designing boilers for over 40 years. It's as much a hobby with him as golf is to others. When he started designing the Big Twin, he figured that the closer he stuck to the proved economy features of our single section Boiler, with its side flue openings and three times back and forth fire travel, the better the boiler would be. Some of us wondered if he wasn't making it so big that Old Man Diminishing Ratio might step in. But Mr. Burnham has a boiler sense, that's so sure it's almost uncanny.

He declared it would steam better than any boiler he had designed.

And it does.

It's tests showed a very high evaporative power per pound of coal burned.

Short Tie Bolts

Each section is snugged-up to its neighbor by short tie bolts.

There are two at the top and one on each side.

Their arrangement is shown in the line sketch below.
Short Grates

One of the best features in this Twin Section boiler is that each twin has its own twin grates. Take a look at the illustration above, and you see that each grate bar extends only half the width of the boiler. The base divisions show the width of a single section. Each division carries four grates, two on either side of the centre support.

The grates on each side work half at a time or four shakes for the whole shake down.

Here at last is the solution to warping grate bars on big boilers; also the difficulty in handling one huge bar weighing never less than 100 pounds, making replacing a most difficult task.

These bars weigh not more than forty pounds and are only 24 inches long.
The Rear End

All operating parts even to the damper handle, being on the front of the boiler, there is nothing on the back but the reversible smoke box and the connection pipe between the section twins, which equalizes the two sides of the boiler.

This pipe is equipped with a draw-off plug.

Smoke Box Reversible

By simply loosening four lugs, the smoke box can be swung around so the pipe can be connected at either side as well as at the top. By shifting the damper plates it can be connected at the back.
Therefore

Here, then, is just the boiler for apartment houses, moving picture theatres, schools, churches and public buildings where tubular boilers have been used.

Being made in sections, no special opening has to be left in the building for its installation. It costs considerably less than tubulars. It will do everything a tubular of same capacity will do, and do it on less coal, and with less attention.

It has lower upkeep with its total absence of tube replacements and the long life of the short length twin grates.

In making these flat comparisons against the tubular, we can do it with perfect consistency as we make tubulars. It always has been our policy, however, to sell a man the thing that will best serve him.

For low pressure work from 4,000 up to 20,000 square feet of radiation, the Cast Iron Twin Sectional Boilers, we heartily recommend.

A Few Installations

A Particularly Interesting Installation Instance

It might be of interest to you to have a non-technical report upon the performance of your 50 Series, 9 Section Low Pressure Steam Heating Boiler, rated at 9775 square foot capacity which I recently specified for the Ballaglia Theatre, Troy, New York.

The heating proposition is installed as a Dunham Vapor System with indirect mechanical heating for the Auditorium, employing plenum chamber under Automatic Control.

Heated air is discharged through Bicakly Mushroom heads located in Auditorium floor, and ventilated air is removed by Bicakly Roof Pan Ventilators.

The fifteen heating stacks containing 1000 square feet of heating surface through which steam is forced by blower. Approximately 3000 square feet of direct cast iron, wall and floor type radiation is used throughout theatre proper and apartments included in this Theatre Building. For the above system I required a free steaming boiler.

This heating plant has been run on two ounces of vapor. The automatic damper regulator has been set at this point and the pressure so maintained. I have run the steam pressure up to 8 pounds in 15 minutes by opening up drafts on the boiler, with full load of direct radiation on.

The performances of the boiler are very satisfactory as to—

1—Fuel Consumption
2—Steaming Capacity
3—Delivery of Dry Steam
4—Steady and Copious supply of steam
5—Extreme simplicity of running and controls

As to quality, design and workmanship the boiler is high class throughout; your grate design is extremely good, making replacement of grate bars, when required, remarkably easy; arrangement of flues and fire travel speak for themselves in performance of boiler.

Castings throughout are true and very heavy.

The six section, same type boiler installed at this plant has not been required as yet, although we have had below zero weather.

When the indirect stack is used excessively, possibly the service of this other boiler may be required.

THE BOILER PIT To obtain the best results it is advisable, whenever possible, to deepen the Ash Pit, either by making a raised foundation under the boiler or by excavating and making a brick or concrete floor under the boiler. This will permit of better draft and consequently improve combustion. Such a sub-pit will also prevent, to a considerable extent, any chance of the grate bars burning out, due to the accumulation of ashes.

GUARANTEE These boilers are guaranteed only to the extent of furnishing new castings for any found defective in manufacture. REPAIRS When ordering repair parts it is important that you give us the Serial Number of the boiler. This will avoid delay in filling the order and will insure the correct pattern being sent. The Serial Number can be found on a small Brass Plate riveted to the Fire Door.

SECTION CEMENT Sufficient asbestos cement is furnished with all boilers to make them gas tight. Cement must be placed between the sections wherever heads or ridges show. It is very important that this be done, as otherwise the gases will "short circuit," and will not have the proper fire travel.

Dear sir,

Finding it necessary to build an extension, 23'x 32', in which to house our new steam heating plant. We asked the Department to add to this extension a second and third storey. To this you consented. A visit to the Mohawk School last week convinced us that we were making a mistake. Light and ventilation are a necessity. Dear Sir -

I regret to report that our Delec plant has gone to pieces. I saw it started myself on Aug. It happened. It started all right. I saw it again shortly after, and it was running as usual. Next thing we knew it was a wreck. On taking it apart we found a broken pin in the piston head had caused the trouble.

(1) The batteries recently purchased are alright.
(2) The machine itself was an early type and imperfect.
(3) It has been in constant use for seven years.
(4) We paid $600.00 on original cost out of school funds.
(5) The plant would have had to be moved into new building, so all things considered it might be worse.

We have shipped the remains to Electric Systems 173 King E Toronto. We would suggest that a new generator be purchased, the remains of which could be applied on price of same. We would greatly appreciate your action as darkness is disastrous here.

With reference to Mr. McVitty's telegram received last week, regarding the Electric Light Plant at the Mount Elgin Institute, I beg to say that the Delco Plant which has been in use for several years is completely worn out, and it is necessary to have same replaced by a new outfit. October 10th, 1926

Dear Sirs,

I have just recently visited the Mount Elgin Institute at Nancey, and find that a very serious situation has arisen regarding the water supply.

As the Department is no doubt aware, the water for the main building, the laundry, and all that is required for the stock in the stables, has been supplied by tile drains which drain the land over hydraulic rams, and the supply has been sufficient for the last sixteen or seventeen years. This year the rainfall has been very light, and every drain but one has dried up, and this one has such a small stream that it is not sufficient to keep the ram in operation. The result is that all the water that is required for the Institute for every purpose has to be hauled from the river, which is proving a very laborious method of supply. If rains come early this fall, and in sufficient quantity, the situation may be remedied. This, of course, is problematical.

One of two methods might be adopted for furnishing the water supply. The first would be to install a pump in connection with the river water and pump the supply from the river. The second would be to bore a well. I have made inquiries regarding deep wells and visited the one nearest to the Institute, which is two miles away. This one is 207 feet deep. If a well were bored, the gasoline engine now installed in the laundry would solve the problem of power. The cost would be the boring of the well and installing of a pump. By this method the tanks that supply the main building could be reached through the present stand pipe, and the water required for the barns and stables could be pumped into the tanks that have been in the past supplied by hydraulic rams, the water graduating from these tanks to the barns.

I would like to hear from the Department concerning this matter, for I fear the result of having
to face winter in such an Institute with no other method of procuring water than by hauling it from the river.

Yours sincerely,

J. Ferrier

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir;

In reply to yours of 23rd inst., No. 7-0-5, permit me to say, we have had very little rain in this district for about four months; result, a water famine from Strathroy north of us, to St. Thomas south of us. Some are beginning to fear that either the Chicago drainage scheme or recent earth shocks have something to do with lowering the water about 10'.

Hoping for a return to normal conditions we have been drawing water from the river for several weeks, but as yet no sign of improvement. All ordinary wells in the district are dry. Deep wells, about 200', are still efficient.

Have consulted deep well borers. Had one come here. All think water can be secured at 200'. They are all so busy it seems almost impossible to get a well down at present, but would like permission to take such steps as necessity may demand, still hoping that a good rainfall may restore normal conditions.

1. We could use present engine and stand pipe.
2. A well costs about $5 per foot.
3. I presume a pump would cost a couple of hundred dollars. All would depend on depth of well.

Respectfully yours,

CONSTRUCTION:

Body: The Body is constructed of Heavy Steel Plate specially selected and tested. To assure rigidity the Body is reinforced with angle iron and closely riveted with steeple-headed rivets driven cold, by hand. The inside of the body and the outside of bottom is alumized, preserving the steel from rust.

Cooking Surface: The Top is of heavy Cast-iron, solid and durable—the surface doubly burnished by the McClary special process.

Firebox:

Grates: The Triple-Bar Grates are powerfully constructed to meet the intense heat and hard wear to which they are subjected. Made from our specially moulded cast iron—three-sided so that the side can be used separately, thus prolonging their life threefold.

Linings: The linings are of pure firebrick, a fabric with extraordinary power of resistance against the destructive effects of the gases from the coal. The bricks are standard size; when worn out after years of service they can be immediately replaced with bricks available locally. Skilled help is also unnecessary when replacement is being made.

Ovens: The top of Oven is provided with a heavy cast-iron stiffener, which adds to the rigidity of the entire Range. The bottom of the Oven is of heavy-gauge steel.

Oven Door: The Oven Door is made from Heavy Steel Plates with wrought-iron frame, reinforced at corners, which hold it firm and rigid. As will be seen from illustration, the drop type is used, with heavy, well-made holders to enable the door, when open, to withstand any weight required of it.

Doors: All other doors are of well-finished cast-iron mouldings and are carefully assembled to swing easily and fit snug when closed.

Bottom: The Bottom of the Range is constructed of Heavy Steel Plate, riveted and securely bolted.

Smoke Box: The Smoke Box is bolted to the body, thus it can be readily removed when it is desired to move the range through an ordinary sized doorway.

FEATURES:

The Army is built on the principle of one oven to one firebox and can be supplied with any number of units to meet the largest requirements. Each unit—the oven and firebox—can be fitted solidly together with a special plate provided for that purpose. The top of the Army is interchangeable, the number of covers or French Plates provided at the discretion of purchaser.

The Burnished Top: The special burnishing process which the cooking top undergoes, renders the surface free from any irregularities and ensures a clean, bright, sanitary surface. The process also toughens the material and gives an extremely well finished surface, pleasing to the eye. A glance at the measurements will demonstrate the exceptional size of the cooking surface—this is a feature much appreciated by the chef and his helpers.

A large sectional ring cover immediately over the fire is supplied with the French Plate top—this permits a utensil of any size to come into direct contact with the fire.

Ovens: The Oven is well proportioned and uniformly heated, interior well finished and smooth.

An additional reinforcement for the top of the Oven is provided through the lining of same with highest quality asbestos. This asbestos is heat-resisting and protects the steel top from direct contact with the heat—it thus prolongs the life of the steel and also tempers the heat when it is at its greatest intensity, so it insures from the firebox.

Flue Construction: The flue construction effectively carries the heat all around the oven. The heat passes over the top of the oven, down the end and the inside of the bottom, passing up the flue at the back of the Range—top, side, bottom and back are, therefore, evenly heated.

Everything in the Army Range is rigid and tight-fitting—there are no loose joints, as they are made perfectly tight with Asbestos Wool; this effectively prevents escape of gases, fumes, etc.

The Range is operated from the front, and dampers are so provided as to be easy of access to the operator.

The Cooking Surface of the Single and Double oven Army can be supplied with full covers or with ring Cover over fire and French Plates.

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, requesting authority to have several rooms in the main building at the Mowin' Kl, In Indian Residential School papered, the cost of which, as stated by you, will not exceed approximately $150.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have this work done. You should purchase the paper and other material required, competitive prices, if possible, being obtained. The work should be done by any labour, and, if necessary, the services of a competent man may be engaged. The staff at the school should assist as far as possible. You will be good enough to see that the work of papering the rooms and any cleaning required is done as cheerfully as possible.

Murray, Ont., July 3rd, 1924

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

In reply to your letter of the 4th inst., No. 7-0-5, permit me to say that we have just returned from a little motor trip, in which we visited the Mohawk Institute, and several other public institutions; and are deeply convinced that whilst the Mount Elgin Institute is well adapted for the work it is intended to do, it certainly is in the matter of "freshness" far behind some of these other buildings. Some parts have never been painted during the fifteen years we have been here, others look quite faded.

For sanitary reasons, for economic reasons, and because the visiting public always expects a Government owned plant to be strictly up to date; I must earnestly request the Department to authorize a much more liberal grant than we asked in our former letter.

I make all the more free to ask this since I have just learned that a class of eleven pupils sent up for high school entrance have all passed, several with honors. Our promotion examinations this year showed marvellous success in class room work, and we have secured the services of a third teacher for next year at a cost of about $1000.00. We are steadily aiming at better things, and feel sure the Department will be a willing partner to a really great forward movement in our school work.

(1) All six dormitories need a coat of paint.

(2) The senior school room needs one coat of paint, and the junior and intermediate rooms two coats each.

(3) Both play rooms need two coats of paint.

(4) The prayer room needs one coat of paint.

(5) The hospital needs a coat and the portion of the old building or the annex which we purpose turning into additional hospital space, needs some burlap on the walls and two coats of paint throughout.

September 18th, 1924

Lunnon C. Scott Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Dr. Scott;

In the hope of securing a more prompt reply I am venturing to approach you personally on a question of vital importance to our school.

1. The tremendous slump in the price of farm produce is cutting our income almost in two. Which means either a less efficient staff of teachers and instructors, or a lower standard of living for the pupils, as I am warned by Dr. Manning that missionary money is very scarce, and there is little hope from that source.

2. We have a splendid herd of about 60 T.B. tested dairy cows, and are forced to sell our cream for a mere trifle above cost of production. Yet really first class butter is difficult to obtain, and still a high price. We have no dairying facilities other than that used on an ordinary farm. I would like very much to start a small creamery of our own for the following reasons.

(1) We would reap the full profit from our herd.
(2) We could afford to give our pupils more butter than at present.
(3) We could manufacture our skimmed milk into cottage cheese, which would make an excellent extra for pupils' table.
(4) We could give our girls a thorough training in first class butter making, and would greatly please the hundreds of farmers and farmer's wives who visit the school.

The cost of equipment would be about as follows:

(1) Small boiler $250.00
(2) Churn and worker $200.00
(3) Vat $125.00
(4) Refrigerator $400.00
(5) Some sundries $25.00, about $1000.00 in all.

I think we could make the boiler serve the purpose of the domestic heater promised us by Mr. Orr, and which would cost about $125.00, and the school has been in need of a refrigerator for years. So these facts taken into account the cost of dairy would be about $300.00. The other things we should have in any case.

Our school is filled to capacity. Prospects brighter than ever. We have a splendid staff, and now just ask what help can you give us in this proposition.

Hoping to receive your very generous consideration,

I am, Dear Dr. Scott,
Yours respectfully,

S. R. McVitty

Dear Sir;

We are in very great need of a cold storage plant of some kind for preservation of milk, butter, and meat during the warm weather. We have nothing whatever of the kind, save a small refrigerator for the upper kitchen.

We are compelled all through the summer to pay retail price for meat, and yet have lots of cattle we could slaughter if we had suitable cold storage.

I drew the attention of both Mr. Ferrier to this condition, during their recent visit. Rev. Ferrier recommended a certain type of building that would cost for material about $500.00 Other men who have large experience say they would prefer a Grocer and Butcher refrigerator, that would cost about $300.00. Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, regarding the renewing of the four soft water tanks in the pupils' dormitories at the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School.

Ottawa, Dec. 5, 1924.

Rev. Sir:

With reference to the well that you were authorized to have sunk some time ago, I beg to advise you that the Architect of the Department, who visited your institution yesterday, has reported that it would be much more satisfactory to install a larger pipe from the existing water supply to the building and place the pump on the building end of the supply pipe.

The question of sinking a well and finding water is very uncertain, and in all probability after expending money on the sinking of the well it would prove unsatisfactory, whereas the installation of the larger pipe, as mentioned above would give us good water supply system for the building, leaving nothing in doubt.

It is noted that you are installing a two inch pipe from the well to the school, at a cost to the Department of 60 cents per foot.

You may, therefore, proceed with this work and endeavour to have same completed before the ground freezes.

January 29th

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Toronto, Ontario.

Dear Sir;

At the time of our diphtheria epidemic last fall the disease invaded the house of our farm instructor. One of his children took it, then his wife who died in a few days leaving him with four small children.

We have done all we could to help him out, paying his funeral expenses and etc., and he has bravely carried on. His children have been scattered among relatives since their mother's death, and I believe there is a chance of getting a housekeeper and wishes to see his children here again.

I was all through his house today. It really needs repainting inside and outside. Not only because it is so shabby, but with a lot of loose paper it is most unsanitary. There would be much risk to his little children returning, and through them to the whole school.

The kitchen has never been plastered. Just bare lath, and the living room floor is wretched. Pine boards about 10" wide, which have been in use probably twenty years.

I would respectfully request therefore, that for sanitary and economic reasons a new floor be put in the living room, the kitchen plastered, the inside woodwork painted, and the walls covered with a clean serviceable paper. The total cost not to exceed $200.00.

Yours respectfully,

The Secretary,

Toronto, Ontario,

Dear Sir;

I permit me to draw your attention to authorization No.7-1925 dated February 2nd '1925.

We papered this farmhouse throughout, and put a real good maple floor downstairs. Our second farmhouse has been vacant for about two years and was sadly out of repair. Windows broken, paper off and generally dilapidated. I felt I could paper the downstairs, parlor, diningroom and kitchen, and still keep inside our grant of $200.00.

We would have been able to do so, but alas, soon as we began to clean off the dirty old paper, down came the plaster ceiling in both parlor and diningroom.

We purchased a beautiful fir ceiling for both rooms as per invoice for $32.00. Put it on, shellaced and varnished it. The expert labor doing so was $20.00, making an outlay of $50.00 more than grant. But we have made a splendid job of both houses instead of one. Both are now occupied.

Had I stopped to get the extra authorization the trip back would have had a second trip to and from Glencoe, about twenty-two miles.

For approval, I am, etc.,

S.R. Mitty

March 27th 1925

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

I beg leave to submit following memo of repairs and alterations at the Mount Elgin Institute; which for reasons of sanitation, economy in upkeep, and for general appearance are absolutely necessary at the present time.

1. There is no drainage whatever from girl's outside toilet, which means a miserable cess pool at times. 30' of 4" tile should be put down connecting with main sewer.

2. A frame garage stands in girl's play ground. It is unsightly and too near main building. It provides a shady corner for dark evenings. It should be removed to a suitable place, put on a proper foundation and painted.

3. An outside slop basin for the lower kitchen is too near door. It should be removed 50' and connected with main sewer by suitable trap and tile.

4. Board fence 6' by 130', separating girl's play ground from wood and laundry yard is completely down and out. It should be replaced by a new fence.

5. Thirty rod of wire fence enclosing orchard, bee and poultry yard has served over 20 years. It is completely done, and should be replaced with hog and cattle proof wire fence.

6. A large wood shed attached to laundry building should be straightened, and put on blocks, and the side facing the main building painted. Also some repairs to roof, which is leaking badly.

7. The posts bearing clothes lines in the laundry yard should be replaced. Several are down and wires sagging.

Dear Sir;

I am in receipt of yours of the 3rd inst., No.7-0-5, and much regret that in reading over official letter of October 14th, No. 7-0-3 I got the impression that Messrs. Eggett and Co had a little latitude in material and time in bringing the job up to date, believing that they had spent the time specified in account and supplied the fittings charged I.C.K. their statement, without reading a second time the original authorization. I now find the contract was quite specific. It was from a hurried reading of the closing paragraph I got the impression.

I took the account as returned, up to Mr. Eggett himself, and asked him to take it up with the men. He now returns the amended account which I herewith submit.

When they informed me that the north school must have two additional radiators to bring it up to standard; I believed that it was the intention of the Department to have the heating made satisfactory, so told them to go ahead and do so. I knew perfectly well that if they once quit the job it would be very difficult and much more expensive to get them back again. And what is even more important this furnace heats two class rooms, hospital and Mr. McCookin's residence, all of which were being used without heat and were getting to be extremely cold.

Our mechanic and I have gone over the work and find he extra fittings charged have been supplied and were absolutely necessary. Time charged was excessive, but when we remember that these workmen brought out these heavy radiators in their own car, one each morning; thereby saving freight and time and certainly endangering their car, it mitigates the offence.

I do not believe Mr. Eggett was a party to the excessive charge, and most certainly I was not. It got past me.

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir:

We have on our school staff a man who has had a long and varied experience as School Principal. He thinks our fire protection is not at all up to standard for a building in which 150 people sleep.

We have gone over the matter very carefully together, and both think that in addition to the very strict preventative measures carried out by our staff, (I make a personal examination of kitchens and furnace rooms almost every night before retiring,) the Department should place about one dozen good sized fire buckets and about half a dozen fire axes in certain strategic parts of the building, and about half a dozen substantial flash lights at the doors of officer's rooms, in case of wiring be destroyed by fire discovery of fire.

These articles to be strictly the property of the Department and to be used in emergency only. Our safety lies in prevention and we must be prepared to meet an incipient fire, once under way we would be absolutely helpless. The fact that a store and residence in our village were wiped out Saturday morning, the house occupied half naked, makes us a bit nervous.

We also need some repairs for cow stanchions in barns, some glass, locks, electric bulbs. About $100.00 in all.

Dear Sir;

I regret to report that one of the large water tanks in main attic, placed there by the late Principal George twenty years ago, has rusted through around the bottom and is leaking badly.

It would soon destroy the ceilings underneath, so we shut it off, but cannot possibly get along without it. I believe it could be turned upside down and rebottomed at about one third the cost of a new tank.

Our mechanic can save connections, but could not do the rebottoming. I would greatly appreciate authorization to have this work done at once. Our needs for domestic purposes and fire protection are very great.

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir,

In respect to certain petitions received from your Township through your Council from time to time, requiring estimates on the cost of supplying power to such petitioners, I am instructed to advise you that all estimates forwarded by this Commission are hereby superseded on account of certain revisions adopted in the manner of serving Rural districts, and chiefly on account of the recent legislation bonusing Rural lines.

I am instructed to advise you that the supplying of power in rural districts shall be conducted after a manner outlined in the revised legislation, part II-B of the Hydro Electric Power Commission Act.

It is required that a proper contract be executed between your Council and the Commission for a supply of power and to permit of the Commission constructing and operating the lines necessary to serve the customers.

The Commission will conduct the business associated with the rendering of service to your customers, and will properly account to your Council for all charges and revenue connected therewith.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6206, file 468-5, part 5)
Users of power in your township will be required to sign a contract with the Township, and may choose, with certain limitations, classes of service outlined as follows:

Class I - Hamlet service includes service in hamlets, where four or more customers are served from one transformer. This class excludes farmers and power users. Service is given under three sub-classes as follows:

I-A Service to residences where the installation does not exceed six lighting outlets or twelve sockets. Use of appliances over 600 watts is not permitted under this class.

I-B Service to residences with more than six lighting outlets or twelve sockets, and stores. Use of appliances over 750 watts permanently installed is not permitted under this class.

I-C Service to residences with electric range or permanently installed appliances greater than 750 watts.

Special or Unusual loads will be treated specially.
Class II - House Lighting - Includes all contracts where residences cannot be grouped as in Class I. This class excludes farmers and power users.

Class III - Light Farm Service - Includes lighting of farm buildings, power for miscellaneous small equipment, power for single phase motors, not to exceed 3 Horse Power demand, or electric range. Range and motor are not to be used simultaneously.

Class IV - Medium Single Phase Farm Service - Includes lighting of farm buildings and power for miscellaneous small equipment, power for single phase motors, up to 5 Horse Power demand, or electric range. Range and motor are not to be used simultaneously.

Class V - Medium 3 Phase Farm Service - Includes lighting of farm buildings and power for miscellaneous small equipment, power for 3 phase motors, up to 5 Horse Power demand, or electric range. Range and motor are not to be used simultaneously.
Class VI - Heavy Farm Service - Includes lighting of farm buildings and power for miscellaneous small equipment, power for motors up to 5 Horse Power demand, and electric range, or 10 Horse Power demand without electric range.

Class VII - Special Farm Service - Includes lighting of farm buildings, power for miscellaneous small equipment, power for 3 phase motors from 10 - 20 Horse Power demand, and electric range.

Class VIII - Syndicate Outfits - Includes any of the foregoing classes which may join in the use of a syndicate outfit, provided the summation of their relative class demand ratings is equal to the Kilowatt capacity of the syndicate.

The estimates on the cost of power delivered to users as herein set out as been based upon certain assumptions, some of which are as follows:

The construction of the lines shall be undertaken and paid for by the Commission. The farmers in the vicinity of the roads along which the lines pass will assist in the construction and assistance will be paid for at a suitable rate of wage. Lines constructed from the line on the highway to customers' premises will be paid for by the
customer. The Commission proposes to supply the necessary expert labor to direct the construction of the lines and the installation of the equipment. It has been assumed that three farmers per mile of line, or the equivalent, are obtainable as an average for the entire district to be served. The supply of poles at low prices in the district or the vicinity of the district by efforts on the part of those desiring service will result in the reduction of the cost of construction and corresponding reduction in the cost of service. Co-operation resulting in the reduction of cost of construction is desired. The rates herein set out are also based upon a government bonus of 50% of the cost of primary lines constructed on the highway or along the right-of-way.

Charges for power delivered shall consist of two parts, namely, the service charge and the consumption charge. The service charge which constitutes the greater portion of the total cost of power delivered, consists of the operating, maintaining and fixed charges of the lines and equipment required to deliver the power to the users in the district. Consumption charges will be determined by a meter at each customers' premises, which will measure the quantity of power used to which a suitable rate will be applied. This cost can only be arrived at when the amount used has been determined. The rate used in the district will be determined by the cost of power at the transformer station supplying the district. The amount of power supplied to the district will be metered at the transformer station.
The meter rates for users in that part of your Township which will be supplied from are estimated as follows:

1. 6¢ per Kilowatt hour for the first 14 hours use per month of customers' class demand rating.

2. 4¢ per Kilowatt hour for all remaining uses.

Less 10% for Prompt Payment.

The following table gives class demand rating, average monthly kilowatt hours, estimated consumption charge, estimated service charge, and total estimated annual cost for each class:

| V Medium 3 phase    |               |                        |                               |                           |                    |

The above costs are calculated from our knowledge of the use of electric power in rural districts under average conditions. They have been adjusted by applying the rates as set out herein.
For those unfamiliar with terms used in power measurement, it is to be noted that one Kilo-watt (K.W.) is approximately equal to 1-1/3 horse power (H.P.) or 3 K.W. equals 4 H.P., and a kilo-watt hour (K.H.W.) is the amount of electricity equivalent to one kilowatt used for one hour.

The rates will be re-adjusted by the Commission from time to time in your district to cover cost. Increase in the average number of farmers per mile or lower cost of power will reduce the annual costs to all.

The Commission upon request by your Council will send a representative to explain the method of rendering service to rural communities, and will assist your Council in securing contracts with individuals desiring service.

Yours truly,

The Secretary,

Ottawa, Ontario,

Dear Sir;

I regret to report that yesterday the floor of our granary collapsed, dumping 1,000 bushel of grain into the pig pen underneath. Fortunately the pigs were out on pasture, and the pens clean so the loss will not be great.

We are moving this grain into horse stable, and other small bins today, but we expect threshers next week and will have another 1000 bushels of grain to take care of, so must get this building straightened up and a new floor in soon as possible. The material will cost about $300.00, as it is quite a large building and is greatly shattered.

We would be greatly pleased to have an authorization to purchase the necessary material. I might add this building is very old. In fact the only one of the old buildings which escaped the fire several years ago, and at present a real eyesore to the whole yard. It needs rebuilding. We would do all the work. Just give us the material.

I am, Dear Sir,

Simple, Solid Construction

This outfit is the most simple in construction of any electric pressure system on the market, with fewest parts.

It is compactly and sturdily built. Motor, switch, pump and pressure tank are all mounted on the one base with no protruding parts. Thus vibration is reduced to a minimum, less space is required for installation, and the appearance of the outfit is considerably improved. The solid base and rigid construction of the pump throughout insure long life and freedom from trouble. Piston rod and stuffing nut are brass. Cylinder is lined with seamless drawn brass tubing.

Owing to the high rate of speed of the pump (220 revolutions per minute) a small belt wheel can be used. The belt wheel on the Beatty Pump is only 10 inches in diameter and the pump is much more pleasing in design and much more convenient for home installations than pumps with the large belt wheel.

As an additional precaution, to insure long life to the system, a safety valve is provided on every pump to protect the pump from undue pressures. Suction strainer in the pump protects it from sediment in the water.

This system is virtually automatic. It can be installed in the cellar or some other out of the way place and left alone for weeks at a time. A little oil now and then is all that is required to keep it in running order.

No cheaper, more satisfactory system has ever been devised to provide water on tap for rural homes.

Memorandum Dr. Scott.

As you know the Ontario Hydro Electric Power Commission have run their power line to Muncey and the wires have been installed leading to the Mount Elgin Institute. Before, however, the current can be turned on it will be necessary to make some changes in the wiring of the building, in order to connect up with the Hydro power and to meet the requirements of the Commission. There will also be required some motors for operating the pump, laundry machinery, etc. The cost of this work, including the motors, will be approximately $2,000.00. In addition to the above it will be necessary to thoroughly examine all of the existing wiring in order to make sure that there are no defects. The cost of this is difficult to estimate but I do not think it will exceed $300.00.

Mr. McVitty has offered to look after the work, the purchasing of materials required, after obtaining competitive prices, and the installation to be done by employing an electrician and a helper. This I believe would be the most economical and satisfactory arrangement, and as the school is practically without lights, due to the fact that the present storage batteries are in such poor condition, I would recommend that Mr. McVitty be authorized to proceed with the work.

Architect.

Dear Mr. Orr:

In reply to yours of the 14th inst., I would say the motor we need is a 7½ horse power, 220 volt, single phase, 25 cycle. All wiring is done ready for it.

Owing to weather conditions it has been impossible to harvest ice this year, and owing to recent heavy rains the last possible chance of doing so is gone. Our grocers and butchers are compelled to install electric refrigeration.

I don't see how we could possibly take care of food for 120 people here without cold storage of some kind. I enclose herewith a tender from the Kelvinator people of London. Have gone carefully into the matter and fully satisfied myself as to efficiency of their system. Their Distributor, Mr. Monigle, is very reliable. Is Mayor of the city for the third time.

If funds are not available for both motor and Kelvinator, we would prefer the Kelvinator at present. We can manage to get our shopping done, but cannot possibly get along without cold storage. Give us both if you can. If not both, then refrigeration by all means. It is absolutely necessary.

that all dormitories are at present furnished with steel fire
escapes, and pupils and staff are repeatedly instructed
as to how to use them in case of fire.

What we greatly need is some sort of
electric alarm system, which could be set off at any one of
several points, and would give a general alarm throughout
the building.

I have taken the matter up with the
Northern Electric people who are specializing in this sort
of equipment. They inform me that a very satisfactory system
can be installed in connection with Hydro at small cost, and
have promised to send out a man at earliest possible date to
go over the matter with me. I will then report results. We
can at the same time add one more steel fire escape if deemed
necessary.

Dear Sir;

The Mount Elgin Institute, is owing to its location immediately South of a great Provincial highway becoming a veritable mecca for tourists, and they have a most intelligent interest in the work we are doing.

We are proud to say our farm, garden, livestock, lawns and grounds are exceptionally fine, and receive most favourable comment from our visitors.

We are just about entering upon our 80th Anniversary year, and hope to make it a memorable one. We expect to greatly strengthen our Staff of instructors, and in our sewing room and workshop produce articles of such merit as to win the complete approval of the crowds we expect to visit us at a great Reunion 17th July next, Anniversary Day.

In this worthy enterprise we respectfully solicit the liberal support of the Department in the matter of improving our buildings and equipment.

1. Our sewing room greatly needs painting and decorating. Also some modern tables and seats. Probable cost of $150.00

2. Our work shop needs about $150.00 worth of benches and machinery used in manual training schools.

3. Our big barns are showing rust, and ought to have two coats of galvanized paint. The pupils can under our instruction do all the side walls, but the roofs are high and very dangerous. For these we would need men used to that kind of work. I presume about $150.00, at 80¢ an hour for outside labour. We can purchase paint at wholesale, about $4.00 per gallon. I think it would take about 50 gallons to go over these barns.

Reverend Sir:

The Superintendent of Indian Education visited the Mt. Elgin Institute during the past week, and he reports that the fire protection is not at all satisfactory. Fire extinguishers are being ordered by the Department and there will be addressed to you a separate letter in this connection. You will please test the hose attached to the standpipe in the main building and make any replacements that are necessary. Further, you should add a fire hose to those standpipes where you consider it advisable. A properly certified accountant, in duplicate, should be forwarded in connection with the purchase of hose.

I understand that the nearest Bridge and Iron Works Company is in London, and I have to ask you to immediately arrange for this firm to quote a price for 2 steel stair fire escapes, properly installed on the rear of the building - one on each wing. As soon as you have received this quotation, please forward it for the Department's consideration.

The Department insists on fire drill at Indian residential schools, and, as soon as the new fire escapes are installed, I know you will carry out our wishes. There is fire hazard in various places in the attic of the school building, and I have to request you to remove any inflammable material which is no longer of use and take other steps to minimize the risk in this portion of the building. Mr. Ferrier noticed an electric iron, and I have to request that the use of this equipment be discontinued.

Our officer reports that the bathing and lavatory facilities for the children are inadequate, and the Department Architect will look into this question upon the occasion of his first visit to the Institute.

Dear Sir,

We have in our laundry yard a large reservoir about 14 x 25 ft. in which is stored water for laundry scrubbing and bathing purposes. This reservoir is covered with wooden planks and then with about a foot of earth. Portions of this covering have fallen through leaving holes which are dangerous to pupils whose duty takes them into the yard as well as to others who may run in during their play period. This reservoir should be cleaned out and a new covering placed upon it.

The smoke pipe of the furnace that heats the junior school room and hospital building is defective; it is 11 in. diameter and about 10 feet long, with two elbows, being close to the ceiling; its defective condition greatly increases fire risk. It should be replaced immediately.

The taps in the boys' and girls' lavatories are worn beyond repair and are causing great waste of water. This with a water famine in sight is a serious matter and should be attended to forthwith.

We hereby request permission to purchase the necessary material for these repairs. Our school mechanic with his boys will provide the labor. The total cost of material should not exceed $200.

Hoping for an early and favorable reply,

I Am

A great deal of interesting and educational entertainment can be provided during the long winter evenings by using this Balopticon. Postcards and snap shots, magazine illustrations and comic strips, coins and curios, in fact an inexhaustible amount of illustrative material can be shown and studied to the enjoyment of both young and old. Pictures and reading matter always appear in the correct position from left to right.

Strip Film Projection

The printing of individual pictures on standard motion picture film offers an inexpensive method of using pictures for educational and entertainment purposes, but their use makes necessary a specially designed projector or an attachment fitting on a standard lantern.

Realizing that many users of our Balopticons would want to use such material, we have designed an attachment for projecting still pictures from strips of film which can be used with any Balopticon.

However, it is likely that many organizations not possessing any projecting lantern at present will be disposed to take up the use of strip film in their religious or educational work, because of the low cost of such pictures, and the ease of handling and transporting. To these purchasers we offer a complete unit film projector, but one so designed that by the purchase of additional parts it can also be used for projecting lantern slides.

Model ABMF—listed on a previous page—is an extremely practical instrument for schools. With a special attachment, slides as well as films can be projected; and with a short focus lens it can be used with a translucent screen under "Daylight" conditions.

July 16th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

I regret to report that the cooking range in our Pupils' Kitchen is quite worn out. It is old and unsightly and a real eye-sore when we are showing visitors through the school. The ovens are so burned out that ashes fall through on to the food being cooked.

This range is the property of the Department and ought to be replaced before school opens after the holidays.

I called at the General Steel Works in London and secured prices which I submit herewith. We find it distinctly advantageous to have goods made in London when we need any repairs.

Hoping for your early favorable consideration of this request,

I am Dear Sir,
Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

September 29th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

I regret to inform you that about a dozen arches over windows and doors of our main building are cracked and the bricks are falling out. I am very much afraid that there is a movement in the river bank which is affecting our foundations. These arches are really dangerous and should be attended to as soon as possible. The work will require a competent bricklayer and the school will provide the necessary unskilled labor. It is very difficult to estimate the exact cost but I feel sure that it will not exceed two hundred dollars for necessary material and labor.

I would be pleased to receive authority to undertake these repairs at once so that they may be completed before the cold weather sets in.

I am dear sir

Yours respectfully,

S. M. Vitty
Principal
Ottawa, October 2, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, requesting authority to incur the expenditure required in repairing the arches over the windows and doors of the main building at the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say that you may arrange to have the repairs absolutely necessary carried out. The Department will expect you to see that all costs for the purpose are kept as low as possible. After the work has been completed, accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded by you in the usual manner covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the material and for the labour required.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

September 4th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

Following your standing instructions of Official Letter I/I/5 April 29th, 1927, I regret to inform you that the Boiler Inspector has condemned the high pressure boiler used in our laundry for many years and forbidden us to fire it up again.

We asked Messrs Leonard and Sons who are the makers of the boiler to send out an expert to examine it for repairs and enclose herewith his report.

We really hesitate to ask the Department for a new boiler but feel that is the cheaper and safer thing to do. A defective or condemned boiler is not permissible where so many girls are at work in the laundry.

We would greatly appreciate an early decision as it is impossible for us to get along without the laundry; the boiler is also used for hot water for bathing purposes.

Awaiting your instructions

I am Dear Sir.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, October 8, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the high pressure boiler in the laundry at the Mt. Elgin Indian Residential School. I note that the Inspector has forbidden its use. The Department concurs that it would be better to secure a new boiler, and you may procure one from the makers at an approximate cost of $391. The enclosure is returned.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

While at Muncey Agency recently I visited the Mount Elgin Institute and in the Senior Class Room I found there were no window blinds. This room gets the sun in the forenoon and afternoon and shades are necessary.

I would recommend that the Principal be authorized to purchase eight window shades and have them installed immediately.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
